finding: The SNP rs117878928 at chromosome 15q25.1 was confirmed as a significant finding in relation to systolic blood pressure (SBP) when interacted with the DASH diet score. The interaction was consistent across populations and showed an effect size of 0.42±0.09 mm Hg in CHARGE and 0.20±0.06 mm Hg in the UK Biobank. Furthermore, the region surrounding rs117878928 was enriched with cis-eQTL and cis-mQTL variants.
title: Genome-Wide Interaction Analysis with DASH Diet Score Identified Novel Loci for Systolic Blood Pressure

finding: The SNP rs75638145-A, a missense variant in TRPM1, was significantly associated with thinning of the INL, IPL, and GCL layers, indicating its potential role in retinal layer dynamics.
title: Insights into human health from phenome- and genome-wide analyses of UK Biobank retinal optical coherence tomography phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs1195500, located at chr15:29687047 in the FAM189A1 gene, was successfully replicated in the Israeli population with a p-value of less than 0.0001 in both genotype and allele testing, after applying Bonferroni correction. This finding confirmed its association with age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
title: Genome-wide association study and genomic risk prediction of age-related macular degeneration in Israel

finding: The rs16969968 SNP, located in the CHRNA5-A3-B4 locus, was positively identified as being related to the heaviness of smoking. It was found that individuals with the AA genotype, carrying two copies of the less common allele, inhaled more smoke when the nicotine content of cigarettes was increased. This SNP was associated with an increase of approximately one additional cigarette consumed per day in smokers. Furthermore, this genetic variant was implicated in various genome-wide association studies related to smoking diseases, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and lung cancer, emphasizing that smoking mediates the association of this locus with these diseases.
title: The causal effect of cigarette smoking on healthcare costs

finding: The SNP rs10902588 was identified as a leading variant on chromosome 15, located in the LRRK1 gene, which encodes a protein involved in B-cell development. It showed a genome-wide significance (P = 1.78 × 10^-8) with an odds ratio (OR) of 2.24, indicating a strong association with anti-NMDAR encephalitis.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies two new loci associated with anti-NMDAR encephalitis

finding: The common variant rs16969968 was associated with smoking behavior, having a minimal effect on daily cigarette consumption (approximately 1 cigarette more; Beta=0.09; CI=0.09-0.10; P=3.8e-125). It represented a well-characterized risk variant at the locus 15q25.1.
title: Rare coding variants in CHRNB2 reduce the likelihood of smoking

finding: The rs17303202 SNP in the RORA gene was associated with COVID-19 positive status, hospitalized COVID-19, and very severe respiratory symptoms, with p-values indicating strong significance (p=2.35E-5 for positive status, p=2.76E-05 for hospitalized status).
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The rs4774377 SNP in the RORA gene showed an association with laboratory-confirmed positive COVID-19 status, with a significant p-value of 8.25E-5.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The rs341419 SNP in the RORA gene was linked to COVID-19 with very severe respiratory symptoms, showing a p-value of 8.13E-4.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The rs12912196 SNP in the RORA gene was associated with gene expression of RORA and showed a strong association with a p-value of 3.9E-5.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The rs145719616 SNP in the SLC12A6 gene was associated with general COVID-19 phenotype with a p-value of 1.19E-4.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The rs192235418 SNP in the SLC12A6 gene was associated with hospitalized COVID-19 status, showing a p-value of 4.42E-4.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The rs2705343 SNP in the SLC12A6 gene showed association with COVID-19 with very severe respiratory symptoms, with a p-value of 1.86E-3.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs11073891 was associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D) in the context of ANPEP polymorphisms, marking it as a novel susceptibility marker.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: The SNP rs12898828 showed a significant association with T2D risk, establishing it as a new susceptibility locus linked to the disease.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: SNP rs12148357 was identified for the first time as being positively associated with T2D risk, further implicating the ANPEP gene in the disease.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: The polymorphism rs9920421 demonstrated a strong association with increased T2D risk, indicating its relevance in the susceptibility landscape.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: This SNP, rs7111, was found to correlate with a heightened risk of developing type 2 diabetes, thereby contributing to the genetic understanding of the disease.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: The rs25653 polymorphism was linked for the first time to an increased susceptibility to type 2 diabetes, highlighting its importance in the ANPEP gene.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: The SNP rs4932143 was strongly associated with both increased T2D risk and altered expression levels of the nearby AP3S2 gene, reinforcing its functional relevance in diabetes pathology.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: rs3784539 was located intronic to CTSH on chromosome 15. It exhibited a suggestive association in celiac disease with a p-value of 1.3 × 10-5, which upon conditional association analysis, also surpassed the genome-wide significance threshold with a p-value of 1.1 × 10-8.
title: Joint analysis reveals shared autoimmune disease associations and identifies common mechanisms

finding: rs7181033 was another independent effect observed in the celiac disease locus. The association yielded a p-value of 8.7 × 10-5, demonstrating its importance in the context of the disease.
title: Joint analysis reveals shared autoimmune disease associations and identifies common mechanisms

finding: This SNP displayed significant associations with traits related to Ewing Sarcoma in the TraitScan analysis, demonstrating its potential involvement in the underlying genetics of the disease.
title: Subset scanning for multi-trait analysis using GWAS summary statistics

finding: The minor allelic variant of rs142312981 (AAG insertion) was significantly associated with lower expression of FAH in former TB progressors but not in non-progressors, indicating a disease-specific regulatory effect in dendritic cells.
title: History of tuberculosis disease is associated with genetic regulatory variation in Peruvians

finding: SNP rs11330240 was recognized as a novel finding linked with cardiovascular traits in the EUR cohort, thus qualified as a positive and original finding.
title: Multitrait Genome-Wide Analysis in the UK Biobank Reveals Novel and Distinct Variants Influencing Cardiovascular Traits in Africans and Europeans

finding: The rs1369031075 variant located in the FRMD5 gene was identified as associated with hospitalization phenotype, with an odds ratio of 4.06, contributing to the genetic understanding of COVID-19 outcomes.
title: Exome-wide association study to identify rare variants influencing COVID-19 outcomes: Results from the Host Genetics Initiative

finding: Variant rs1036476 was identified as an intronic variant in the FBN1 gene and contributed significantly to the causal inference concerning aortic annulus area and aortic valve regurgitation.
title: Genetic architecture of cardiac dynamic flow volumes

finding: The SNP rs6495309 served as another lead SNP associated with GrimAge DNAm pack years. This SNP is also recognized in the GWAS Catalog and is related to nicotine dependence, a significant factor in smoking behavior.
title: Blood- and brain-based genome-wide association studies of smoking

finding: The SNP rs10152355 was associated with angina risk, showing an odds ratio (OR_IVW) of 1.005, with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 1.003–1.007, and a p-value less than 0.001. This finding suggested a positive relationship between genetically determined serum MUFAs and the risk of angina.
title: Causality of Genetically Determined Monounsaturated Fatty Acids on Risk of Cardiovascular Disease: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The SNP rs2642636 was associated with atherosclerotic disease, with an odds ratio (OR_IVW) of 1.005 and a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 1.003–1.007, along with a p-value below 0.001, reinforcing its relevance to cardiovascular risk.
title: Causality of Genetically Determined Monounsaturated Fatty Acids on Risk of Cardiovascular Disease: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The SNP rs12185072 exhibited a positive correlation with ischemic heart disease (IHD), with an odds ratio (OR_IVW) of 1.004, 95% CI: 1.001–1.007, p = 0.005, supporting its association with cardiovascular risk.
title: Causality of Genetically Determined Monounsaturated Fatty Acids on Risk of Cardiovascular Disease: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The SNP rs174418 was linked to both IHD and myocardial infarction risk. For IHD, it had an odds ratio (OR_IVW) of 1.004 with a confidence interval of 1.001–1.007 and p = 0.005, reflecting its contribution to cardiovascular diseases.
title: Causality of Genetically Determined Monounsaturated Fatty Acids on Risk of Cardiovascular Disease: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The SNP rs61999891 was associated with myocardial infarction, showing an odds ratio (OR_IVW) of 1.001, 95% CI: 0.999–1.003, although this finding was not statistically significant (p = 0.199), hinting at a possible role in MI risk.
title: Causality of Genetically Determined Monounsaturated Fatty Acids on Risk of Cardiovascular Disease: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The GLCE variant rs3865014 was associated with various health parameters including BMI, blood hemoglobin levels, hypertension, and cerebrovascular events as evidenced in the TAMRISK study, highlighting its multifaceted impact on health.
title: Variability in proteoglycan biosynthetic genes reveals new facets of heparan sulfates diversity. A systematic review and analysis

finding: The SNP rs2036527 was identified as a top-ranked variant for creatinine-standardized total nicotine equivalents (TNE) and was associated with various tobacco-related phenotypes, including cigarettes per day (CPD). It showed a significant effect size (beta = 0.57, p = 1.4E-5) and was located proximal to the CHRNA5 gene in the chr15q25.1 region, known for its roles in nicotine dependence and lung cancer susceptibility.
title: Multiethnic Prediction of Nicotine Biomarkers and Association with Nicotine Dependence

finding: The SNP rs55676755 was trained in all penalized regression models for TNE and supported associations with pulmonary diseases based on previous genome-wide studies. The findings indicated that this variant may serve as a predictor of smoking-related toxicant exposures among various ethnic groups.
title: Multiethnic Prediction of Nicotine Biomarkers and Association with Nicotine Dependence

finding: Within the same GWAS, rs35859241 emerged as a lead variant with a significance of p = 3.69 x 10^-8. It operates as an eQTL for SCG3 and GLDN in brain tissue, indicating its importance in influencing gene expression relevant to cognitive functions.
title: Genome-wide association study in 404,302 individuals identifies 7 significant loci for reaction time variability

finding: The SNP rs2606134 was located within the 5’ untranslated region of SCG3 and demonstrated a significant association with p = 1.14 x 10^-4. It had a CADD score of 13.15 and a RegulomeDB score of 2b, suggesting its biological relevance and potential impact on gene expression.
title: Genome-wide association study in 404,302 individuals identifies 7 significant loci for reaction time variability

finding: The p.R82C variant in RAB27A was linked to hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) (OMIM: 267700) and exhibited a significantly enriched AF of 0.5% in the Qatari population, with higher frequencies of 2.7% in Arabs and 0.1% in Bedouins, while being absent in global datasets.
title: Genetic landscape of rare autoinflammatory disease variants in Qatar and Middle Eastern populations through the integration of whole-genome and exome datasets

finding: The SNP rs4932477 was found to be a novel suggestive signal associated with chromosome 15, notably containing the gene POLG, which is linked to severe intractable monogenic epilepsy.
title: Genome-wide meta-analysis of over 29,000 people with epilepsy reveals 26 loci and subtype-specific genetic architecture

finding: Colocalization with both SCZ and BIP GWAS was observed for this variant located in intron 13 of the FURIN gene. It was in moderately strong linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs4702, which has been validated as an eQTL.
title: Cross-ancestry, cell-type-informed atlas of gene, isoform, and splicing regulation in the developing human brain

finding: This SNP located in the 3' UTR of the FURIN gene was CRISPR-validated as an eQTL and linked to neuropsychiatric disorders including schizophrenia.
title: Cross-ancestry, cell-type-informed atlas of gene, isoform, and splicing regulation in the developing human brain

finding: The rs58365910 variant near CHRNA5 indicated a suggestive association with laryngeal cancer, correlated with increased smoking intensity.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The rs1051730 variant had previously established associations with smoking volume and was analyzed in the context of its influence on disease prevalence for both COPD and IPF. The findings indicated a strong association between the number of rs1051730 alleles and increased odds of COPD, specifically showing a genetically instrumented one-unit higher smoking volume linked to a 7.15-fold higher odds of COPD in ever smokers (OR=7.15; 95%CI:4.73-10.8; P=9.3×10−21). In contrast, for IPF, there was no substantial evidence of a causal relationship, as the odds ratio was found to be 0.45 (95%CI:0.06-3.28, P=0.43), indicating a lack of association across smoking strata for IPF.
title: A Mendelian randomisation study of smoking causality in IPF compared with COPD

finding: SNP rs4702, located in the FURIN gene, was identified in the MTAG analysis and had previously been shown to be GWS in OUD GWAS.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: The SNP rs16969968 on the CHRNA5 gene was found to be predictive of maternal smoking behavior, supporting its role as an indicator of genetic predisposition to smoking. Mothers of children with two risk alleles for this SNP exhibited higher maternal smoking rates compared to those with zero risk alleles, although this difference diminished towards the end of the study period.
title: The prevalence, trends and heterogeneity in maternal smoking around birth between the 1930s and 1970s

finding: The homozygous nonsense mutation in BLM (c.581_582delTT;p.Phe194*) was identified in patient F3/II-2 and was predicted to be pathogenic. It had an allele frequency of 8 × 10−6 in the ExAC database. This variant was also detected in another patient (F4/II-2), confirming its association with Bloom syndrome (BS), characterized by primary microcephaly and immunodeficiency.
title: Phenotypic distinctions of BLM- and RMI1-associated Bloom syndrome

finding: A homozygous missense variant in BLM (c.3164G>C;p.Cys1055Ser) was found in two siblings (F5-II/2 and F5-II/3) who had consanguineous parents. This variant, located in exon 16 of BLM with an allele frequency of 17 × 10−6, contributed to the severe phenotype of BS, affecting the protein's helicase enzyme activity.
title: Phenotypic distinctions of BLM- and RMI1-associated Bloom syndrome

finding: The missense variant rs113298164 (p.Thr405Met) in LIPC was associated with higher serum apolipoprotein-A1 levels (p=7.8×10^-8). Carriers of this variant had a median serum apoA-1 of 163 mg/dl compared to 138 mg/dl in non-carriers.
title: Novel protein-altering variants associated with serum apolipoprotein and lipid levels

finding: The p.Phe368Leu variant in LIPC was associated with higher apoA-1 levels in a separate GWAS analysis (p=0.02).
title: Novel protein-altering variants associated with serum apolipoprotein and lipid levels

finding: The variant was nominally associated (p=0.04) with apoA-1 but had low imputation quality (0.37) and low MAF (0.0002).
title: Novel protein-altering variants associated with serum apolipoprotein and lipid levels

finding: The SNP rs2472297 was reported to have a significant association with clozapine plasma concentrations. This 13kb upstream variant was implicated in the regulation of the CYP1A2 gene, suggesting that it plays a role in influencing clozapine metabolism.
title: Rare Variants in Pharmacogenes Influence Clozapine Metabolism in Individuals with Schizophrenia

finding: This SNP was linked with THBS1 in the context of its modifying effects on DMD severity, showing substantial p-value support in earlier studies.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of loss of ambulation in dystrophinopathy patients suggests multiple candidate modifiers of disease severity

finding: The SNP rs55707100 was found within the gene MAP1A, with a compelling association indicated by a p-value of 2.61×10^-15, marking its relevance in heart failure risk.
title: Exploring novel risk loci for heart failure and the shared genetic etiology with blood lipids, blood pressure, and blood glucose: a large-scale multi-trait association analysis

finding: The SNP rs12917449 was found to be positively associated with type 2 diabetes. This association emphasized its significance as a genetic predictor in diabetes, while also indicating a potential link to insomnia.
title: Exploiting collider bias to apply two-sample summary data Mendelian randomization methods to one-sample individual level data

finding: The SNP rs1847325 in the gene CERS3 was significantly associated with increased brain glucose metabolism in the bilateral frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes, indicated by corrected p-value < 0.05 in a voxel-wise analysis of FDG PET imaging, which correlates with Alzheimer's Disease (AD) pathophysiology.
title: Multi-Omic Analyses Characterize the Ceramide/Sphingomyelin Pathway as a Therapeutic Target in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs71137385 was linked to PML in breast cancer through 3' aQTL analysis, indicating its potential role in cancer susceptibility.
title: Large-scale alternative polyadenylation (APA)-wide association studies to identify putative susceptibility genes in human common cancers

finding: The variant rs11852372 was linked to higher levels of the protein CTSH in plasma and coincided with sentinel variants that showed positive associations with lung cancer in the studies conducted, which highlights its significant finding in the context of proteomic implications in lung cancer.
title: Machine learning-based proteogenomic data modeling identifies circulating plasma biomarkers for early detection of lung cancer

finding: rs12914385 was associated with elevated plasma levels of CTSH and was recognized as a sensitive variation related to lung cancer risk in the findings of the study.
title: Machine learning-based proteogenomic data modeling identifies circulating plasma biomarkers for early detection of lung cancer

finding: The variant rs55781567 showed a positive association with lung cancer risk, linked to higher protein levels of CTSH in plasma, thereby reinforcing its relevance in the identified cancer-related variants.
title: Machine learning-based proteogenomic data modeling identifies circulating plasma biomarkers for early detection of lung cancer

finding: The SNP rs12901653 in CHD2 was found to interact with cumulative prenatal stress to influence DNAm at the nearby site cg24317086. The association was significant (B=-0.026, SE=0.003, p=4.07×10^-16). This finding suggested a role of maternal stress exposure on the DNAm of genes adjacent to CHD2, specifically related to CHASERR, which is implicated in regulatory RNA functions.
title: Interactive effects of genotype with prenatal stress on DNA methylation at birth

finding: The low-frequency variant rs528350911 was identified within a crucial regulatory enhancer region associated with increased risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D) and other glycemic traits. It was found that this SNP was linked to significant glycemic associations including random glucose levels and T2D adjusted for body mass index (BMI), with odds ratios indicating a notable risk. The strength of its association with T2D was comparable to that of the lead SNP rs7903146 at the TCF7L2 locus, underscoring its importance in diabetes research. The data suggested the variant's role in pancreatic development, affecting insulin secretion rather than insulin sensitivity.
title: A ONECUT1 regulatory, non-coding region in pancreatic development and diabetes

finding: Located at 15q25.1, this SNP was identified as a variant associated with lung cancer susceptibility, corroborating previous findings from GWAS.
title: Genetic analysis of lung cancer reveals novel susceptibility loci and germline impact on somatic mutation burden

finding: This SNP at 15q25.1 was confirmed as a susceptibility locus for lung cancer, reinforcing earlier GWAS results.
title: Genetic analysis of lung cancer reveals novel susceptibility loci and germline impact on somatic mutation burden

finding: This SNP, also located at 15q25.1, was implicated in lung cancer susceptibility, consistent with prior research.
title: Genetic analysis of lung cancer reveals novel susceptibility loci and germline impact on somatic mutation burden

finding: The genetic variant rs16969968 was associated with increased tolerance to nicotine, leading individuals to be heavier smokers. This SNP had a significant relationship with smoking behavior, indicating that those who inherited more risk alleles tended to smoke more cigarettes per day on average.
title: A multivariable Mendelian randomisation study exploring the direct effects of nicotine on health compared with the other constituents of tobacco smoke: Implications for e-cigarette use

finding: The SNP rs10851907 was identified as the main genetic variant in the cotinine GWAS. However, this SNP showed a conditional weakness due to its linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs16969968, which is known to be associated with smoking heaviness. This weakness raised concerns about the confidence in estimating the direct effect of nicotine on smoking-related health outcomes.
title: A multivariable Mendelian randomisation study exploring the direct effects of nicotine on health compared with the other constituents of tobacco smoke: Implications for e-cigarette use

finding: This SNP was noted as shared between anxiety and both bipolar disorder and schizophrenia, implicating its role in the genetic intersections of these disorders.
title: Identification of Novel Genomic Loci for Anxiety and Extensive Genetic Overlap with Psychiatric Disorders

finding: The statistical and epigenomic fine-mapping prioritized rs12906125 in the promoter of the FES gene as the likeliest causal variant at its locus associated with BP regulation. This variant is a stronger eQTL for FES than for the nearby gene FURIN, supporting the hypothesis that FES contributes to BP modulation although pLoF variants in FES were found to be associated with BP.
title: Association analyses of predicted loss-of-function variants prioritized 15 genes as blood pressure regulators

finding: The SNP rs11634680 demonstrated a suggestive association with John Henryism (JH), replicating findings from a prior study. The odds ratio (OR) was 0.74 with a confidence interval of 0.61 to 0.86, and a P-value of 6.2×10^-7, which confirmed the association in both studies.
title: Genome-wide association study of John Henryism in the CARDIA Cohort suggests a molecular mechanism behind lower nicotine addiction rates

finding: Fine-mapped SNP rs4702 was found to overlap a neuronal enhancer and showed a causal role in bipolar disorder by decreasing cortical expression of FURIN.
title: Fine-mapping genomic loci refines bipolar disorder risk genes

finding: The SNP rs916977 was strongly associated with the fractal dimension, Df, with a P-value of 7.41·10^-48. This association was noted to have relevance in the context of pigmentation studies, as well as in the connection to coronary artery disease (CAD).
title: Decreased retinal vascular complexity is an early biomarker of MI supported by a shared genetic control

finding: The SNP rs12913832 exhibited a very strong association with Df, indicated by a P-value of 2.16·10^-96. This finding was also linked to pigmentation, and the emerging relationship between Df and CAD further substantiated its significance.
title: Decreased retinal vascular complexity is an early biomarker of MI supported by a shared genetic control

finding: The intergenic sentinel variant facilitated identification of risk associations in the AF locus, serving as an indicator for genetic influences.
title: Genetic associations of protein-coding variants in human disease

finding: A rare variant in HCN4 was linked to increased AF risk, consistent with documented familial bradycardia associations.
title: Genetic associations of protein-coding variants in human disease

finding: The SNP rs1979409 in the NEO1 locus was significantly associated with the occurrence of left common trunk pulmonary veins (LCT-PVs) in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF). This association was supported by a significant difference in the polygenic risk score (PRS) between patients with LCT-PVs and those with normal pulmonary veins (p=1.64e-05).
title: Left common trunkus pulmonary veins have genetic background and poorer rhythm outcome after paroxysmal atrial fibrillation catheter ablation

finding: The SNP rs2043085 was linked to lipid-wide associations in the BHS cohort, indicating its relevance in the genetic regulation of lipid species and potentially in the context of coronary artery disease.
title: Comprehensive genetic analysis of the human lipidome identifies novel loci controlling lipid homeostasis with links to coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs3825807, located in the ADAMTS7 gene, was found to be associated with a significantly reduced risk of incident coronary artery disease (CAD) among never-smokers, with a hazard ratio (HR) of 0.89 (95% CI: 0.84–0.93; p=1.1×10⁻⁵). In contrast, no significant association was observed for ever-smokers (HR: 0.96; 95% CI: 0.92–1.01; p=0.14). Additionally, rs3825807 was associated with an increased risk of pneumonia (HR: 1.08; 95% CI: 1.03–1.12; p=4.4×10⁻⁴) among ever-smokers but not among never-smokers (HR: 0.96; 95% CI: 0.92–1.01; p=0.15). This indicates a statistical interaction between smoking status and this SNP's effect on both conditions.
title: Genome-wide pleiotropy analysis of coronary artery disease and pneumonia identifies shared immune pathways

finding: The SNP rs55781567 located at 15q25.1 in the CHRNA5 gene was identified as a smoking-related locus. It also exhibited higher frequencies and stronger association effects in the white population, further illustrating the genetic factors underlying the risk of lung cancer associated with smoking in this ethnic group.
title: Ethnic differences of genetic risk and smoking in lung cancer: two prospective cohort studies

finding: The rs4702 variant, located in the 3' UTR of the FURIN gene, was successfully fine-mapped by SuSiEx, confirming it as a potential causal variant with strong population-specific causal probabilities of 1.000 in EUR and 0.976 in EAS. Although it did not achieve genome-wide significance in EAS (P = 1.06E-3), this variant has been previously associated with schizophrenia, corroborating its relevance as a significant genetic marker across populations.
title: Fine-mapping across diverse ancestries drives the discovery of putative causal variants underlying human complex traits and diseases

finding: rs2472297 was associated with coffee and caffeine intake, lying in the intergenic region between CYP1A1 and CYP1A2, which are involved in xenobiotic metabolism, and also linked to alcohol consumption, clozapine pharmacokinetics, kidney function, and urine biomarkers. This SNP replicated several prior findings from coffee GWAS.
title: Genome-Wide Association Studies of Coffee Intake in UK/US Participants of European Ancestry Uncover Gene-Cohort Influences

finding: The T allele for rs7178051 was associated with a 12% reduced risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) among smokers. The association indicated that the T allele led to lower ADAMTS7 mRNA expression, and it was highlighted that smoking could counteract this protective effect by upregulating ADAMTS7 expression without additional risk for non-carriers.
title: Improving Genetic Association Studies with a Novel Methodology that Unveils the Hidden Complexity of All-Cause Heart Failure

finding: The SNP chr15:50716490:T:C was identified as a damaging missense variant in the gene SPPL2A, which completely co-segregated with the common variant within AD-FBS families, marking its significance in familial Alzheimer’s disease.
title: Identification of Rare Damaging Missense and Loss of Function Variants in GWAS Loci Using Genome Sequencing Data from Two Cohorts of Familial Late-Onset Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP chr15:58753575:A:G related to the gene ADAM10 was identified as a damaging missense variant that completely co-segregated with the common variant in the EFIGA families, suggesting its potential role in Alzheimer's disease pathology.
title: Identification of Rare Damaging Missense and Loss of Function Variants in GWAS Loci Using Genome Sequencing Data from Two Cohorts of Familial Late-Onset Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs28665122, associated with a promoter polymorphism in the SELENOS gene, was noted to correlate with increased endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress and elevated production of inflammatory cytokines in carriers of the A-allele. The context of this finding indicated that the suppression of SELENOF, SELENOM, SELENOK, and SELENOS by SARS-CoV-2 may exacerbate ER stress and contribute to a cytokine storm in susceptible individuals, particularly amidst selenium deficiency which compromises GPX1 production.
title: SARS-CoV-2 suppresses mRNA expression of selenoproteins associated with ferroptosis, endoplasmic reticulum stress and DNA synthesis

finding: The SNP rs3826007-T, located at locus 15q25.1, was previously associated with a decreased count of flow-sorted monocytes, with GWAS p-values below 5×10^-83 in several studies. This association was further clarified as it specifically linked to the selective depletion of CD16+ monocytes with a GWAS p-value of 5×10^-9. The allele was found to encode a deleterious glycine to aspartic acid missense change in the BCL2A1 gene, which is essential for monocyte survival. A decreased expression of BCL2A1 was also noted in whole blood, with eQTL p-value of 9.3×10^-52, thereby implicating that the csaQTL might reduce CD16+ monocyte abundance by producing a dysfunctional form of the BCL2A1 protein.
title: Identifying genetic variants that influence the abundance of cell states in single-cell data

finding: The SNP rs11070913 was linked to a study that investigated differentiation induction in response to irradiation in neural stem cells. This finding was contextualized within the framework of p53's role in regulating the cellular DNA damage response and its potential connection to developmental defects, particularly microcephaly, triggered by hyperactivation of p53 during neurogenesis. The research underscored the involvement of p53 in activating genes associated with differentiation and response to DNA damage.
title: p53 drives premature neuronal differentiation in response to radiation-induced DNA damage during early neurogenesis

finding: This SNP was found on chromosome 15 at locus 15q14 and had a z-score of 7.11, impacting asymmetries of connectivity in key brain regions like the rolandic operculum.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: Located on chromosome 15, this SNP is in high LD (r2=0.76) with rs28520337 and was previously associated with cortical surface area.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: The SNP rs11071017 was identified as a positive and original finding in the context of colorectal cancer and its association with the serrated pathway. This SNP was linked to differential microbiome compositions, particularly associated with the presence of tubular adenomas and serrated polyps, where distinct microbiome signatures were observed compared to polyp-free individuals.
title: Distinct Colon Mucosa Microbiomes associated with Tubular Adenomas and Serrated Polyps

finding: Included in the 12 FDR significant SNPs recognized through the Flexible cFDR method due to its high GenoCanyon score.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: The SNP rs2470890 was found in CYP1A2, with an elevated frequency in all non-African populations. It had a CADD score ≥ 20, indicating a likely impact on function, and was noted in the Papuan population at a frequency of 12.5%.
title: Archaic introgression and variation in pharmacogenes and implications for local adaptation

finding: SNP rs381001 exhibited a significant association with moldability in yams, where genotypes with the AC allele had medium scores, emphasizing its effect on texture.
title: Detecting the genetic variants associated with key culinary traits in Dioscorea alata

finding: As part of the group of ASCA-SNPs with significant associations, rs111261603 exhibited variability in correlation with formative and primed RNMs, thereby suggesting its relevance in the genetics of pluripotency.
title: Unsupervised Machine Learning Identifies Chromatin Accessibility Regulatory Networks that Define Cell State Transitions in Pluripotency

finding: The SNP rs35811129 was associated with the estimated length of long TCF4 alleles, indicating that it influenced TCF4 repeat expansion in blood cells. The association was statistically significant with p-values ranging from 1.3×10^-5 to 9.1×10^-13 when conditioning on imputed allele length, suggesting a strong genetic contribution to TCF4 repeat instability.
title: Insights into the causes and consequences of DNA repeat expansions from 700,000 biobank participants

finding: The SNP rs12050863 was linked to the genetic variation that contributed to the accuracy of LiDAR-based measurements of individual tree diameter and height in integrated crop-livestock-forest systems. This finding emphasized the SNP's relevance for improving biomass estimation and hence carbon sequestration potential in forests.
title: Quantifying Forest Biomass and Genetic Contribution using Light Detection and Ranging

finding: The SNP rs35828350 demonstrated differing regulatory effects; it upregulated NMB in the fetal cortex, which encodes a neuropeptide, while downregulating WDR73 in the adult cortex, highlighting its dual role across developmental stages.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: The rs290164 variant was noted for having a notable difference in frequency between populations (ΔDAF = 28%), explaining approximately 76% of the differences in isomiR ratios for miR-146a-3p, further highlighting population-specific effects on miRNA expression.
title: Population variation of miRNAs and isomiRs and their impact on human immunity to infection

finding: The SNP rs775026151 led to an A915V mutation in the BLM gene, linked to Bloom syndrome and hereditary breast and ovarian cancer.
title: Predicting functionally important breast cancer SNPs using pleiotropy, conservation, and protein structure

finding: The SNP rs2568494, located in the IREB2 gene, was associated with the risk of developing Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). The analysis indicated that individuals carrying certain alleles of this polymorphism exhibited a significantly increased likelihood of COPD, emphasizing the genetic contribution to this chronic disease.
title: Fibroblast-derived Osteoglycin Promotes Epithelial Cell Repair

finding: The rs77004004 variant in the ATP8B4 gene was designated as damaging, with no additional context related to its health effects reported.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing-based Characterization of Human Genome Variation and Mutation Burden in Botswana

finding: The finding regarding rs2652822 indicated that this SNP was significantly associated with plasma succinylcarnitine levels in two large population-based European cohorts, with a p-value of 7×10^-27. This suggests a strong genetic influence on the metabolism of succinylcarnitine, potentially implicating the LACTB gene in metabolic regulation, particularly relating to body mass index, as it positively correlated with Lactb mRNA expression (p=1.19×10^-8). Moreover, the expression of Lactb transgenes was demonstrated to impact fat mass in mice, indicating its phenotypic relevance.
title: High Throughput Computational Mouse Genetic Analysis

finding: The SNP rs11071010 was associated with lung-seeking metastases as reported by Stella et al. in their study published in Cancers (Basel) in 2019. This finding was significant within the context of understanding how metastatic processes affect the lung, particularly noting its implications in mapping the differential remodeling of respiratory function in lung diseases.
title: Probing lung function at high spatiotemporal resolution using a novel crystal ribcage

finding: The SNP rs783540 was linked to AP3B2, which is a member of the AP-3 complex. It had splicing and expression QTL associations with AP3B2 but was ranked higher for the disruption of CPEB1, as the variant lies within a CPEB1 intron. This finding illustrated the genetic interactions associated with schizophrenia, highlighting AP3B2's potential role as a causal gene at its locus.
title: An atlas of protein-protein associations of human tissues prioritizes candidate disease genes

finding: Val433Met (rs2306022) was identified as a sentinel cis pQTL for ITGA11 and conferred risk for Dupuytren contracture and uterine fibroids, indicating its relevance in these conditions.
title: Large-scale comparison of immunoassay- and aptamer-based plasma proteomics through genetics and disease

finding: This newly identified SNP rs28866311 showed a significant interaction with the DLL4 gene, which is involved in angiogenesis through Notch signaling. Its association with blood pressure traits was established in the context of vascular function.
title: Chromatin interaction maps of human arterioles reveal new mechanisms for the genetic regulation of blood pressure

finding: The SNP rs16969968 on chr15q25 was previously established as a functional missense variant in CHRNA5 associated with nicotine dependence (ND). It had a highly significant association with ND in prior studies, reinforcing its role in smoking behavior.
title: Expanding the Genetic Architecture of Nicotine Dependence and its Shared Genetics with Multiple Traits: Findings from the Nicotine Dependence GenOmics (iNDiGO) Consortium

finding: The SNP rs3784789 was associated with lower DNA methylation at the cg26843110 locus, which corresponded with shorter gestational ages at birth. This SNP's influence suggested a connection between maternal smoking, placental epigenetic changes, and regulatory effects on growth-related genes.
title: Placental DNA methylation signatures of maternal smoking during pregnancy and potential impacts on fetal growth

finding: rs17293632 was noted as a Ref-ASB for 25 different transcription factors and was previously reported to affect chromatin accessibility in the nearby region. It was associated with Crohn's disease and located in the intron of the SMAD3 gene, overlapping an eQTL targeting SMAD3, AAGAB, and PIAS1 genes. A variant of SMAD3 was also found to be associated with Crohn's, especially relating to increased risk of repeated surgeries and shorter relapse.
title: Landscape of allele-specific transcription factor binding in the human genome

finding: The rs16969968 SNP in the CHRNA5 gene was associated with cognitive deficits and neuronal pathophysiology in rats, mimicking conditions present in humans with this polymorphism. Results from the study indicated that neurons from rats expressing this SNP exhibited significant changes in dendritic morphology, specifically longer apical dendrites, and showed altered synaptic properties when compared to wild-type (WT) and alpha5 knockout (KO) rat neurons. Importantly, L6 regular spiking (RS) neurons carrying the rs16969968 SNP demonstrated decreased spine density, suggesting aberrant synaptic plasticity, which has implications for psychiatric disorders like schizophrenia and nicotine dependence.
title: Linking Altered Neuronal and Synaptic Properties to Nicotinic Receptor Alpha5 Subunit Gene Dysfunction: A Translational Investigation in Rat mPFC and Human Cortical Layer 6

finding: The SNP rs12101693 was associated with responses to Grapevine Leafroll-Associated Viruses (GLRaV) in grape cultivars. Findings indicated its potential impact on disease resistance, specifically showing how hyperspectral imaging methods could detect infection in vineyards.
title: Assessing the capacity of high-resolution commercial satellite imagery for grapevine downy mildew detection and surveillance in New York state

finding: The non-coding SMAD3 variant rs8040709 was identified as a centenarian-enriched intronic variant that altered binding of ELK1, resulting in reduced SMAD3 expression, senescence, and inflammation in endothelial cells, thereby contributing to human longevity.
title: Longevity-associated SMAD3 non-coding centenarian variant impairs a cell-type specific enhancer to reduce inflammation

finding: The SMAD3 variant rs8040749 was prioritized as a potential causal variant because it created a binding site for ETS family transcription factors, specifically ELK1, which enhanced binding and decreased SMAD3 enhancer activity, contributing to reduced SMAD3 expression associated with longevity.
title: Longevity-associated SMAD3 non-coding centenarian variant impairs a cell-type specific enhancer to reduce inflammation

finding: The T allele of rs2168518 in hsa-miR-4513 was associated with increased susceptibility to coronary artery disease (CAD), particularly in European populations, which showed a high frequency of this allele (61%). This suggests environmental and genetic risk factors contributing to CAD across populations.
title: Signatures of genetic variation in human microRNAs point to processes of positive selection related to population-specific disease risks

finding: This SNP was associated with microcephalic osteodysplastic primordial dwarfism and epileptic encephalopathy. It highlighted genetic influences crucial for prenatal brain development and craniofacial coordination.
title: Derived Homo sapiens cis-eQTL regulation: implications for brain evolution

finding: The study reported that the G allele of the schizophrenia-associated SNP rs4702 was linked to a downregulation of FURIN expression by miR-338-3p. This downregulation subsequently reduced the production of BDNF, which is a neurotrophic factor important for neuronal health and development. This finding highlighted the molecular mechanisms through which genetic variants may influence the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.
title: The kpc-1 3’UTR facilitates dendritic transport and translation of mRNAs for dendrite arborization of a mechanosensory neuron important for male courtship

finding: The SNP rs1426654 was determined to be the lowest-cost characteristic SNP for the third split in the tangles tree, which separates European and South Asian populations. This SNP is associated with iris color and skin pigmentation in South Asians, indicating its relevance to population phenotypic traits.
title: Inferring Ancestry with the Hierarchical Soft Clustering Approach tangleGen

finding: The study found the strongest associations for rs2033939 at 15q14 with cortical thickness (CTh) and cortical volume (CV) in the postcentral cortex, with p-values of 1.17×10^-73 for CTh and 4.34×10^-133 for CV. This indicates significant genetic influence on these cortical measures.
title: Genetic Determinants of Cortical Structure (Thickness, Surface Area and Volumes) among Disease Free Adults in the CHARGE Consortium

finding: For rs1080066 at 15q14, a strong association was observed with cortical surface area (CSA) in the precentral cortex, with a p-value of 8.45×10^-109. This suggests a significant genetic contribution to surface area measurements in primary motor areas.
title: Genetic Determinants of Cortical Structure (Thickness, Surface Area and Volumes) among Disease Free Adults in the CHARGE Consortium

finding: The SNP rs11071010 was associated with increased lung metastasis in the study described, where human-specific glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) RT-qPCR detected elevated lung metastasis linked to the expression of aldehyde dehydrogenase 1A3 (ALDH1A3) in MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells implanted in NOD/SCID mice. This finding indicated that there might be a genetic predisposition related to the SNP and its influence on metastasis, which was further investigated in the context of cancer research.
title: Human-specific GAPDH RT-qPCR is an accurate and sensitive method of xenograft metastasis quantification

finding: The SNP rs150393409 tagged a significant effect (15AM1) at FAN1, where variants impacted clinic and molecular distinctions in blood and somatic findings.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs151322829 was noted for its role in genetic modification of phenotypic features associated with the FAN1 pathway (15AM3), highlighting mechanisms of pathogenic influence.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs118089305 emerged from analyses as relevant to genetic modulation of the FAN1 gene and participated in both clinical and molecular modifier effects (15ABEM4).
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs61260387 was part of a notable association with increased CAG expansion at FAN1 but showed a discrepancy in clinical outcomes, indicating its complex role in pathogenesis.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs3512 demonstrated partial correspondence in both clinical and somatic studies but maintained distinct patterns in effect on expansion.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs8031627 was associated with the exon-intron-ratio of SMAD3, a transcription factor involved in the transforming growth factor-beta signaling pathway. It colocalized with GWAS variants related to lung function (FVC), highlighting its potential influence on this trait.
title: Disentangling genetic effects on transcriptional and post-transcriptional gene regulation through integrating exon and intron expression QTLs

finding: The SNP rs4778055, associated with the novel long non-coding RNA gene ENSG00000258922, was similarly categorized as having an induced effect, reflecting significant G×T interactions.
title: Probabilistic classification of gene-by-treatment interactions on molecular count phenotypes

finding: At the SLC24A5 locus, early selection for skin pigmentation alleles occurred, with the selected allele reaching near fixation by about 3,500 years ago, suggesting early adaptations to UV radiation contexts.
title: The Selection Landscape and Genetic Legacy of Ancient Eurasians

finding: The SNP rs3809566 was noted as a sentinel GWAS SNP associated with platelet traits. It was linked with the TPM1 gene, and its analysis indicated the relationship of genetic variations at this locus to platelet related phenotypes, which included potential implications for hematopoiesis.
title: Machine learning-based identification and cellular validation of Tropomyosin 1 as a genetic inhibitor of hematopoiesis

finding: The SNP rs11071720 was located within the 3rd intron of the TPM1 gene and identified as an eQTL associated with decreased TPM1 expression. The minor allele disrupted a GATA binding site and was correlated with higher platelet count and lower MPV, thus highlighting its role in hematopoiesis.
title: Machine learning-based identification and cellular validation of Tropomyosin 1 as a genetic inhibitor of hematopoiesis

finding: The minor allele for the high-scoring SNP rs4075583, which was in linkage disequilibrium with rs3809566, was associated with decreased TPM1 expression in certain heterologous cells. This finding, although not consistent in GTEx tissues, offered insights into the genetic control of hematopoiesis related phenotypes.
title: Machine learning-based identification and cellular validation of Tropomyosin 1 as a genetic inhibitor of hematopoiesis

finding: The variant rs12913832 in the HERC2 gene was found to modulate human pigmentation by attenuating chromatin-loop formation between a long-range enhancer and the OCA2 promoter. This finding contributes to understanding how genetic variants influence pigmentation traits and may also relate to predisposition to conditions associated with pigmentation, such as melanoma, which is discussed in the context of MC1R signaling and its role in pigmentation and cancer susceptibility.
title: Loss of MC1R signaling implicates TBX3 in pheomelanogenesis and melanoma predisposition

finding: In context to SNP rs12929673 (related to TERF2IP), the CAD risk allele was associated positively with lower expression in females and higher in males, indicating a differential impact based on sex.
title: Genetic regulation of human aortic smooth muscle cell gene expression and splicing predict causal coronary artery disease genes

finding: The variant rs117799466 increased the binding affinity for multiple transcription factors (TFs) known for their repressive roles, notably SP1, ZN281, and MAZ. This has been linked to the downregulation of SLC12A6, a gene critical for potassium uptake, implicating a mechanism of repression that may contribute to glial dysfunction in schizophrenia.
title: Unveiling causal regulatory mechanisms through cell-state parallax

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was found to modulate human pigmentation by attenuating chromatin-loop formation between a long-range enhancer and the OCA2 promoter. This finding provided insight into the molecular mechanisms underlying variations in pigmentation traits in humans, highlighting the influence of chromatin conformation on gene regulation.
title: Common DNA sequence variation influences 3-dimensional conformation of the human genome

finding: The SNP rs1426654 in the SLC24A5 gene was observed to be more prevalent in populations such as Altai_MLBA and Chandman_IA that exhibited lower Eastern Eurasian affinity, suggesting it underwent positive selection among these groups as a part of the broader genetic landscape.
title: A dynamic 6,000-year genetic history of Eurasia’s Eastern Steppe

finding: Similar to rs1229984, the SNP rs1800414 in the OCA2 gene showed low frequencies during the MLBA and EIA, but an increase was noted as East Asian ancestry became more prominent in the populations examined, signifying a positive selection trend.
title: A dynamic 6,000-year genetic history of Eurasia’s Eastern Steppe

finding: The SNP rs11070923 was identified as significant in the context of intrinsic resistance mechanisms present in cancer cells. Although specific correlation with TNBC was less emphasized, it was part of a comparative analysis addressing resistance patterns in various cancer pathologies.
title: Resistance patterns in drug-adapted cancer cell lines reflect the complex evolution in clinical tumours

finding: The variant rs184950120, located 5'UTR to MKRN3, displayed a weaker effect in males (beta = 0.085 years/allele for voice-breaking) compared to females (beta = 0.396 years/allele for menarche). This suggests a notable difference in the effects of this variant between sexes.
title: Expanded genomic analyses for male voice-breaking highlights a shared phenotypic and genetic basis between puberty timing and hair colour

finding: The SNP rs16942341[T] was found to be strongly associated with decreased height. Its effect was measured at -0.13 SD with a p-value of 4.0·10^-27 in a large GWAS of 183,000 individuals of European descent. This SNP is highly correlated (LD R2 = 0.96) with the 5-motif deletion in ACAN, which also showed significant association with height.
title: Long read sequencing of 3,622 Icelanders provides insight into the role of structural variants in human diseases and other traits

finding: The study identified a target-site mutation, specifically D70N, in the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor alpha5 subunit associated with thiamethoxam resistance in the laboratory-selected resistant strains of Euschistus heros. This finding provided insight into the molecular mechanisms of resistance to neonicotinoid insecticides.
title: Transcriptomic investigation of the molecular mechanisms underlying resistance to the neonicotinoid thiamethoxam and the pyrethroid lambda-cyhalothrin in Euschistus heros (Hemiptera: Pentatomidae)

finding: The rs3809508 SNP in the neuromedin B gene was found to be associated with the risk of obesity, particularly influenced by maternal educational level. This finding was reported in the context of the HELENA study, suggesting that polymorphisms in NMB predispose individuals to obesity through their effects on appetite control and feeding preferences.
title: Neuropeptide Neuromedin B does not alter body weight and glucose homeostasis nor does it act as an insulin-releasing peptide

finding: The germline variant rs34988193 in the ANKDD1a gene was associated with poor prognosis in both the TCGA and CGGA datasets (p=0.001, HR=1.73, FDR < 0.10). This variant causes an amino acid change from lysine to glutamate and was predicted to be among the top 0.06% of deleterious mutations in the human genome. The similar hazard ratios in both datasets indicated its reliability as a prognostic marker.
title: The Germline Variants rs61757955 and rs34988193 are Predictive of Survival in Low Grade Glioma Patients

finding: The SNP rs10468017 at the LIPC locus was associated with hypercholesterolemia, suggesting it plays a significant role in lipid metabolism regulation.
title: Genome-wide association study of plasma triglycerides, phospholipids and relation to cardio-metabolic risk factors

finding: The lead variant rs35028925 demonstrated a strong association with lung cancer risk and was found to be in proximity to the STRC gene, which was identified in both breast and ovarian cancer analyses. This association illustrated the potential pleiotropic effects of genetic variants across multiple cancer types.
title: Pleiotropy-guided transcriptome imputation from normal and tumor tissues identifies new candidate susceptibility genes for breast and ovarian cancer

finding: The SNP rs3759916 was part of the three main SNPs in the promoter region of the ST8SIA2 gene associated with schizophrenia risk and promoter activity across multiple populations, including Asians and Europeans. Its non-risk haplotype (CGC-type) was positively selected mainly in Asia over the last 20-30 thousand years, indicating an adaptation to psychosocial stress.
title: Lower promoter activity of the ST8SIA2 gene has been favored in evolving human collective brains

finding: SNP rs3759915 was among the three SNPs identified to regulate schizophrenia risk linked to the ST8SIA2 gene. The CGC-type, involving this SNP, was found to undergo positive selection primarily in Asian populations, suggesting its role in adapting to psychosocial stress.
title: Lower promoter activity of the ST8SIA2 gene has been favored in evolving human collective brains

finding: The SNP rs3759914 was included in the trio of SNPs associated with schizophrenia risk in the ST8SIA2 gene's promoter region. It indicated a positive selection of the non-risk haplotype (CGC-type) in Asia, reflecting adaptation against psychosocial stress factors.
title: Lower promoter activity of the ST8SIA2 gene has been favored in evolving human collective brains

finding: The rs10046 SNP was associated with Alzheimer's disease risk as part of a meta-analysis involving 11,051 subjects, suggesting its significance in the genetic predisposition to dementia.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The rs1143704 SNP was included in the systematic review and meta-analysis correlating several aromatase gene polymorphisms with Alzheimer's disease, indicating its relevance to disease risk.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The rs767199 SNP was analyzed in the context of its association with Alzheimer's disease risk among a large cohort, pointing to its potential impact on disease development.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The rs727479 SNP exhibited associations with Alzheimer's disease risk, as shown in the systematic review which indicated its importance among a diverse subject pool.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The rs1065778 SNP was analyzed alongside other aromatase gene polymorphisms in relation to Alzheimer's disease, signifying its potential contribution to disease susceptibility.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The rs1062033 SNP was part of a larger analysis linking aromatase gene polymorphisms to Alzheimer's disease risk, underlining its potential relevance in the genetic landscape of dementia.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The rs1008805 SNP was associated with the risk of developing Alzheimer's disease based on the findings of a systematic review involving thousands of participants.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The rs700519 SNP was included in the analysis of several polymorphisms correlating with Alzheimer's disease risk, suggesting its involvement in genetic predisposition to this form of dementia.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The SNP rs11072494 was part of a set of four variants linked to congenital craniofacial abnormalities. It was associated with multiple downstream trans-eGenes, including GPR160, SEMA3A, MDFIC, GRIK2, FAM169A, and GLB1L3. The analysis indicated a significant enrichment for biological pathways such as the JNK cascade and MAPK cascade, which are known to be implicated in congenital craniofacial abnormalities.
title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: The SNP rs2289187 was identified as one of four variants linked to congenital craniofacial abnormalities, correlating with six downstream trans-eGenes (GPR160, SEMA3A, MDFIC, GRIK2, FAM169A, and GLB1L3). This SNP, along with others in the set, was associated with significant enrichment in biological processes related to the JNK cascade and MAPK cascade.
title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: The SNP rs10459648 was included in the set of four variants connected to congenital craniofacial abnormalities, influencing expression of six downstream trans-eGenes. Its association outlined specific biological pathways such as the JNK cascade and MAPK cascade, which are relevant to these congenital conditions.
title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: The SNP rs6495117 also featured in the group of four variants linked to craniofacial congenital abnormalities. It affected the expression of six downstream trans-eGenes and indicated significant enrichment in biological pathways (the JNK and MAPK cascades) associated with these types of abnormalities.
title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: SNP rs6224 showed the strongest association between surface area (SA) and schizophrenia (SCZ), with a harmonic mean p-value (HMP) of 3.66×10^-8. This association highlights the genetic link between SCZ and variations in cortical surface area.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs28661259 was associated with increased CT in the cingulate cortex for SCZ, pointing towards its relevance in cortical functions.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs883669 was implicated in connections with greater SA in orbitofrontal cortex for SCZ, highlighting its genetic importance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: rs8028409 was identified as part of a credible set of 17 SNPs associated with breast and ovarian cancer, where the A (risk) allele was significantly linked to decreased expression of the RCCD1 gene in both normal breast and ovarian tissues. Additionally, rs8028409 was determined to be the top eQTL (expression Quantitative Trait Locus) for RCCD1 expression in breast tumors, confirming its role in tumor biology.
title: Transcriptome and interactome analyses identify the TP53 interacting gene RCCD1 as a candidate susceptibility gene at the 15p26.1 breast and ovarian cancer risk locus

finding: rs8037137 was also included in the credible set of 17 SNPs related to breast and ovarian cancer, with the T (risk) allele showing a significant association with decreased RCCD1 expression in both tissue types. The SNP was identified as a lead risk variant and exhibited the highest effect on RCCD1 expression in cancer cell lines among the tested alleles.
title: Transcriptome and interactome analyses identify the TP53 interacting gene RCCD1 as a candidate susceptibility gene at the 15p26.1 breast and ovarian cancer risk locus

finding: The SNP rs17293632 was highlighted as a single nucleotide variant identified through multiple genome-wide association studies (GWAS). It was recognized as an important modifier of the risk for myocardial infarction. Specifically, this SNP lies within a functional smooth muscle enhancer. Although it was established that SMAD3 modifies smooth muscle cell differentiation and proliferation through interactions with other transcription factors critical to smooth muscle cell biology, the mechanisms by which Smad3 expression, influenced by this SNP, specifically impacts plaque biology and myocardial infarction risk remained unclear.
title: Smad3 Regulates Smooth Muscle Cell Fate and Governs Adverse Remodeling and Calcification of Atherosclerotic Plaque

finding: The SNP rs11635336, located in a region associated with the genes IL16 and STARD5, was linked to significant upregulation of the L1 transposon family. GSEA showed a strong upregulation correlated with genotype changes in this region, indicating a regulatory role in L1 RNA levels.
title: An eQTL-based Approach Reveals Candidate Regulators of LINE-1 RNA Levels in Lymphoblastoid Cells

finding: The SNP rs2472297 found in the CYP1A2 gene was also significant for tea drinking, similar to rs4410790, though leaving this SNP out of the analysis didn’t change the overall results for PD risk.
title: The Parkinson’s Disease Mendelian Randomization Research Portal

finding: The significant association detected through variant rs2165241 in LOXL1 was indicative of reduced retinal detachment risk and highlighted potential pleiotropic effects.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: The variant rs8028374 (A/G) was identified as a puQTL associated with the external promoter of the TTC23 gene (prmtr.35339) with a highly significant p-value of 6.99 x 10^-18 and a beta coefficient of -0.56, indicating that this variant influenced the activity of this specific promoter.
title: Mapping of promoter usage QTL using RNA-seq data reveals their contributions to complex traits

finding: SNP rs4702 was confirmed as the top causal SNP for FURIN expression in the analysis. It was synthesized into the study’s library of SNPs and played a significant role as a positive control in determining transcriptional activity shifts in the context of the reported experiments.
title: Dynamic stress- and inflammatory-based regulation of psychiatric risk loci in human neurons

finding: The SNP rs12913832 located at the HERC2 locus indicated a p-value of 5.21 × 10-10, classifying it as a previously suggested but not previously significant signal of selection.
title: Scalable probabilistic PCA for large-scale genetic variation data

finding: It was found that rs17228058 was associated with IBD and was located near the SMAD3 gene. This SNP also participated in mQTLs, indicating its involvement in the aberrant DNA methylation patterns observed in IBD.
title: The DNA Methylome of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) reflects intrinsic and extrinsic factors in intestinal epithelial cells

finding: The SNP rs1426654 related to the SLC24A5 gene, which plays a role in melanogenesis. Ancestral allele frequencies were nearly fixed in the native Mexican populations, such as northern Mexico populations, indicating possible relaxation of selection or an adaptive event favoring the ancestral state. The derived allele is known to decrease skin pigmentation and was heavily studied in European populations.
title: Population history and gene divergence in Native Mexicans inferred from 76 human exomes

finding: In the context of the eight overlapping SNPs, the study identified a high no-call rate (89.6%) caused by interference between adjacent SNPs. For rs1800414 specifically, the SNP had a low amplification concentration, resulting in a heterozygous genotype call, which supported the notion of allele out-competition due to spike-in DNA.
title: Doctoring Direct-to-Consumer Genetic Tests with DNA Spike-Ins

finding: The SNP rs4932178 was identified as a key driver in the model predictions for coronary artery disease (CAD). It resided in a putative enhancer for the gene PRC1 and was also located within the promoter region of the FURIN gene, which is known to influence monocyte-endothelial adhesion and was linked with CAD through its role in vascular remodeling.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: The SNP rs113028686 appeared in both the classic and resAdj TPOT pipelines, particularly noted for its location in the 5' UTR of the gene PRC1. It was recognized as an eQTL for the FES gene across various tissues and was instrumental in model predictions for CAD.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: The SNP rs8031684, located within an intron of PRC1, was identified as an eQTL for RCCD1 in adipose, aortic, and tibial artery tissues, highlighting its relevance to CAD.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: The SNP rs11073964, positioned just upstream of PRC1, was characterized as a missense mutation for VPS33B, which is associated with novel susceptibility loci for early-onset myocardial infarction.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: The SNP rs17636091 was found within an intron of PRC1 and recognized as an eQTL for both RCCD1 and VPS33B, thus underscoring its involvement in the CAD-related pathways.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: SNP rs12908161, associated with schizophrenia, had a posterior colocalisation probability of 1.00 with an i-eQTL targeting the unannotated expressed region DER36302, indicating a strong regulatory relationship and highlighting its potential link to the disease.
title: Regulatory sites for known and novel splicing in human basal ganglia are enriched for disease-relevant information

finding: The SNP rs950169 colocalised with the i-eQTL targeting DER36302, showing an eQTL p-value of 1.15 × 10^-10 in putamen. This SNP also had significant GWAS p-value indicating its relationship with schizophrenia.
title: Regulatory sites for known and novel splicing in human basal ganglia are enriched for disease-relevant information

finding: The SNP rs3043909 was associated with the forced expression of ZNF143, which was found to restrain cancer cell growth. This finding highlighted the role of ZNF143 in regulating genes that influence cancer biology, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for cancer treatment.
title: Putative Looping Factor ZNF143/ZFP143 is an Essential Transcriptional Regulator with No Looping Function

finding: The study indicated that patients with the homozygous alternative genotype (GG) for rs1065080 were high responders to roflumilast plus fluticasone, contrasting with poor responders where only 5 of 13 displayed this genotype.
title: Application of Pharmacogenomics and Bioinformatics to Exemplify the Utility of Human ex vivo Organoculture Models in the Field of Precision Medicine

finding: This variant demonstrated the strongest association with coffee consumption among genetic instruments, but when assessing its relationship with breast cancer risk, it did not support a significant association.
title: Coffee consumption and risk of breast cancer: a Mendelian Randomization study

finding: Identified among outlier SNPs for ER-positive breast cancer suggesting an association, but specifics regarding coffee consumption were not established.
title: Coffee consumption and risk of breast cancer: a Mendelian Randomization study

finding: The A allele of the regulatory SNP rs1979905 was associated with higher CHRNA5 expression and significantly reduced cortical β-amyloid load. This association demonstrated neuroprotective roles for CHRNA5 in aging and Alzheimer's disease.
title: CHRNA5 links chandelier cells to protection against amyloid pathology in human aging and Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The homozygous A allele of the missense SNP rs16969968 was associated with impaired function and trafficking of nicotinic α5-containing receptors, leading to significantly lower proportions of chandelier cells in individuals with high β-amyloid loads, thus suggesting increased vulnerability of these neurons.
title: CHRNA5 links chandelier cells to protection against amyloid pathology in human aging and Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs1080066, located on chromosome 15, was identified as having significant associations with regional brain morphology measures, particularly impacting regional surface area and cortical thickness. The statistical significance of this correlation was noted to be exceedingly high (p=1.2×10−305), implicating it in the genetic architecture of brain structure.
title: Making the MOSTest of imaging genetics

finding: The rs4702 SNP located within the 3' region of the gene FURIN was observed to be effectively edited using a CRISPR-based approach. In a bulk analysis of editing efficiency conducted on hiPSC lines, it was found that editing accidents were successful in 5 out of 5 evaluated hiPSC lines, with editing efficiencies ranging from 21.7% to 52.2%. This finding illustrates the potential for manipulating this risk variant associated with schizophrenia through targeted genetic engineering.
title: Publicly available hiPSC lines with extreme polygenic risk scores for modeling schizophrenia

finding: The SNP rs1426654, identified in the SCL24A5 gene, was noted for having a significant effect on skin pigmentation. The analysis included conditioned effect sizes that indicated a substantial variance contribution attributable to this variant.
title: Interpreting SNP heritability in admixed populations

finding: The SNP rs8040347 was reported in a study by Tien Bui et al. (2016), which focused on mapping tropical forest fire susceptibility. The finding indicated that the presence of certain genetic markers could influence fire susceptibility in tropical forest ecosystems, providing context for how genetic factors might correlate with environmental responses to fire. This study utilized GIS-based kernel logistic regression to analyze the correlation, highlighting the significance of genetic factors in ecological dynamics.
title: Fire traps in the wet subtropics: new perspectives from Hong Kong

finding: This SNP was identified as a causal variant in SLC24A5, associated with skin and eye pigmentation in Europeans.
title: Ohana: detecting selection in multiple populations by modelling ancestral admixture components

finding: In the context of cancer treatment strategies, rs11071014 was associated with the effectiveness of HDM2 (MDM2) antagonists, which are designed to restore p53 activity. The study by Kocik et al. (2019) indicated that the SNP is correlated with enhanced anticancer activity when used in drug combinations targeting the p53 regulatory network.
title: Shared gene regulatory strategies for the p53 and ATF4-dependent transcriptional networks

finding: The rs17293632 SNP at the SMAD3 locus was also found in significant smooth muscle cell peaks in relation to CAD.
title: Cell-specific chromatin landscape of human coronary artery resolves regulatory mechanisms of disease risk

finding: The SNP rs8030221 was associated with diverse response phenotypes in young beech trees, particularly in relation to drought resistance. The findings indicated that saplings from the Iberian Peninsula exhibited the least trait change in response to drought stress, which was interpreted as a signature of greater drought resistance linked to specific genetic variations at this locus.
title: Leaf spectroscopy reveals drought response variation in Fagus sylvatica saplings from across the species’ range

finding: SNP rs7165633 was linked to Mobiluncus mulieris in females, highlighting its potential role in microbial communities associated with vaginal health and infections.
title: M-GWAS for the gut microbiome in Chinese adults illuminates on complex diseases

finding: The SNP rs597414 was implicated in a study related to type 2 diabetes, where it was selected by the block HSIC Lasso due to its low p-value (p = 1.781 x 10^-7). This selection did not adhere to a conservative p-value threshold, instead prioritizing SNPs that improved classification accuracy in the context of identifying genetic factors associated with type 2 diabetes.
title: Block HSIC Lasso: model-free biomarker detection for ultra-high dimensional data

finding: At SNP rs8023408, individuals with A/A genotype exhibited increased SV2B expression in bulk glomerular tissue. This was attributed to an EndoG specific eQTL effect, highlighting the SNP's role in modulating gene expression in specific kidney cell types.
title: Mapping the genetic architecture of human traits to cell types in the kidney identifies mechanisms of disease and potential treatments

finding: The SNP rs76930569 C/T was associated with positive natural selection, exhibiting a p-value of 1.1 × 10^-12. It was indicated that this variant was in complete linkage equilibrium with another SNP, rs1800414, which affects melanin biosynthesis.
title: Exploring the genetic diversity of the Japanese Population: Insights from a Large-Scale Whole Genome Sequencing Analysis

finding: The SNP OCA2 rs1800414 showed significant positive natural selection signals with an earlier increase in the derived allele frequency around 25,000 years ago, associated with traits of light skin color and tanning ability, reflecting adaptations to varying environmental sunlight conditions across East Asia.
title: Exploring the genetic diversity of the Japanese Population: Insights from a Large-Scale Whole Genome Sequencing Analysis

finding: The SNP rs2073711 (A/G), located in the CILP gene, was identified as a TIM. Its temporal variation indicated an increase in the frequency of the risk allele, likely related to lifestyle transitions and dietary changes in ancient populations.
title: A genomic dating tool for ancient genomes resolves the origins of hundreds of Eurasian genomes
