finding: The SNP rs7183877 (C/A) is part of a haplotype within the HERC gene, associated with blue eye color. It demonstrated temporal variation, suggesting selection pressures associated with pigmentation traits in populations.
title: A genomic dating tool for ancient genomes resolves the origins of hundreds of Eurasian genomes

finding: The SNP rs8028689 (T/C), also within the HERC gene, showed temporal frequency variation indicating selection pressure. It was linked to pigmentation, particularly in Caucasian populations.
title: A genomic dating tool for ancient genomes resolves the origins of hundreds of Eurasian genomes

finding: The CYP19A1 rs3751592 variant conferred susceptibility to Alzheimer's disease specifically in the Chinese Han population, emphasizing the SNP's impact on neurodegenerative conditions.
title: Screening key genes and signaling pathways in COVID-19 infection and its associated complications by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: Variants near rs261290 were previously associated with HDL, TC, and TG, indicating their relevance in lipid metabolism across multiple traits.
title: MetaPhat: Detecting and decomposing multivariate associations from univariate genome-wide association statistics

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was found to modulate human pigmentation by attenuating chromatin-loop formation between a long-range enhancer and the OCA2 promoter. This finding was related to the phenotypes of hair and eye color, which were well-replicated in the study using the GenNet framework.
title: GenNet framework: interpretable neural networks for phenotype prediction

finding: The SNP rs2238307 was significantly correlated with IDH2 and implicated in the broader genetic landscape related to age-related macular degeneration.
title: Transcriptomic and proteomic retinal pigment epithelium signatures of age-related macular degeneration

finding: Identified in PARP12, rs3825991 showed a high correlation with rs2238307, suggesting its significance in the pathways involved in geographic atrophy.
title: Transcriptomic and proteomic retinal pigment epithelium signatures of age-related macular degeneration

finding: The variant rs16964465 was found to affect the transcriptional activity of the SCG3 gene, where the minor allele containing haplotype was protective against high obesity, as supported by an odds ratio of 9.23 (p=7 × 10⁻⁶). This finding is particularly notable as the variant was absent in European-ancestry groups but common in African and East-Asian populations.
title: A survey of proteomic variation across two ethnic groups in Nigeria and its relationship to obesity risk

finding: Similar to rs16964465, the variant rs16964476 was reported to influence the transcriptional activity of SCG3, indicating a protective effect against high obesity risk. Both variants were highlighted as significant findings in regulating obesity in African ancestry.
title: A survey of proteomic variation across two ethnic groups in Nigeria and its relationship to obesity risk

finding: The SNP rs16969968 on chromosome 15 was examined for its effect on FEV1, which is a well-established risk locus for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and cigarette smoking. The analysis involved three regression models to assess the association p-values for rs16969968 on FEV1 in the context of both regional and global principal components. This approach was intended to evaluate the potential benefits of including regional principal components in the analysis. The analysis was conducted using data from the COPDGene study, resulting in a sample of 5,765 subjects and 94,497 rare variants.
title: locStra: Fast analysis of regional/global stratification in whole genome sequencing (WGS) studies

finding: This SNP was associated with coronary artery disease in East Asians, showing a negative effect (beta=-0.073, p=5.97×10^-13), indicating its impact on cardiovascular phenotypes.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: This SNP was associated with apolipoprotein A in European populations, highlighting its importance in lipid metabolism.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: This SNP was linked to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in East Asians, indicating its relevance in respiratory phenotypes.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: The index SNP rs62013139 was identified as linked to allele-specific GOM (genome-wide methylation differences) in multiple myeloma. It showed strong ASM with hypermethylation of the REF allele in cancer samples, indicating its regulatory role in this malignancy.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: This SNP caused a stop gained mutation in the gene HYKK, and was identified as significant in the context of blood metabolite associations, including the metabolite levels associated with genetic variance.
title: Genome-microbiome interplay provides insight into the determinants of the human blood metabolome

finding: The SNP rs11633209 was identified as a significant candidate cis-eQTL affecting the expression of the gene LPAR6, with an adjusted p-value of 1.96×10⁻⁶⁶. This SNP contributed to the maternal expression pattern in regulating LPAR6's gene expression.
title: A statistical method for joint estimation of cis-eQTLs and parent-of-orign effects using an orthogonal framework with RNA-seq data

finding: The SNP rs4965238 was discovered to have a significant dominance effect on the expression of the IGF1R gene, with an adjusted p-value of 1.37×10⁻⁶⁷. This SNP showed both dominance and imprinting effects, marking its crucial role in gene regulation associated with complex diseases.
title: A statistical method for joint estimation of cis-eQTLs and parent-of-orign effects using an orthogonal framework with RNA-seq data

finding: This SNP had the highest odds ratio (OR=20.1) in the context analyzed, being associated with glaucoma, a condition that typically manifests post-reproductive age. Despite its strong association with disease, it was noted that selection coefficients were largely unlinked from the effects of GWAS loci on disease risks.
title: Ancient DNA reveals that few GWAS loci have been strongly selected during recent human history

finding: The SNP rs2278458, located in the CYFIP1 gene, was found to be associated with triglyceride levels and response to diuretics among individuals of European and African ancestry. It revealed a shared DAP region across multiple populations.
title: Continental-scale genomic analysis suggests shared post-admixture adaptation in Americas

finding: Similarly, rs1426654 demonstrated a significant correlation with non-European ancestry. Its genotyping was crucial for correcting population designations in samples associated with the SUZ12P1-CRLF3 chimeric RNA, indicating that non-European individuals were more likely to express this gene fusion.
title: Discovery of A Polymorphic Gene Fusion via Bottom-Up Chimeric RNA Prediction

finding: At the 15q14 locus, variant rs684374 was found in a glucocorticoid-responsive chromatin site bound by the glucocorticoid receptor. It exhibited significant allelic effects on chromatin accessibility specifically in glucocorticoid-treated islets and disrupted a sequence motif for the glucocorticoid receptor, indicating a role in glucocorticoid signaling.
title: Glucocorticoid signaling in pancreatic islets modulates gene regulatory programs and genetic risk of type 2 diabetes

finding: The rs16969968 SNP was identified as a major target in disease, particularly in the context of its role in nicotinic receptor alpha5 coding. This finding highlighted its significance in understanding the functional implications of nAChR variability related to respiratory diseases and the pathology of lung tissues in smokers and non-smokers.
title: Nicotinic receptors atlas in the adult human lung

finding: The SNP rs1129038 was identified as the best-ranked variant in the EUR group, known to inhibit gene regulation, which affects the blue eye color phenotype. This was determined through selection scans that pinpointed alleles in strong linkage disequilibrium with sweeping alleles.
title: Modeling recent positive selection in Americans of European ancestry

finding: The SNP rs11070946 was associated with the radiobiological effects of proton beam therapy, specifically impacting DNA damage and repair mechanisms in irradiated skeletal muscle cells, as described by Vitti and Parsons in their 2019 study. The findings highlighted the importance of understanding how genetic factors could influence cellular responses to ionizing radiations, particularly in relation to different ionizing particle characteristics, and their effects on DNA integrity and stability in cancer treatments.
title: The DNA damage response relies on the characteristics of ionizing particles in myogenic cells

finding: The SNP rs184852001, located at chromosome 15:98876579, was identified in a variant-based GWAS with a genome-wide significant p-value of 1.9e-08. However, it was not found in the largest BMI meta-GWAS.
title: Quantitative Genetic Scoring, or how to put a number on an arbitrary genetic region

finding: The SNP rs7163757 was linked to the gene C2CD4B in alpha cells. Previous studies demonstrated that this SNP was associated with C2CD4B expression and corroborating functional studies supported these findings.
title: Single cell ATAC-seq in human pancreatic islets and deep learning upscaling of rare cells reveals cell-specific type 2 diabetes regulatory signatures

finding: The SNP rs17293632, when analyzed, was found to significantly alter binding of the AP-1 transcription factors and was associated with autoimmune phenotypes like ankylosing spondylitis (AS), Crohn's disease (CR), multiple sclerosis (MS), psoriasis (PS), rheumatoid arthritis (RA), and ulcerative colitis (UC).
title: The AP-1 factors FOSL1 and FOSL2 co-regulate human Th17 responses

finding: A rare missense variant (rs139709573, NP_510883.2:p.P155L) in TM2D3 was significantly associated with increased risk of developing late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) with an odds ratio of 7.45 (pMETA = 6.6×10^-9). This variant was also correlated with an earlier age-at-onset of up to 10 years difference, with a hazard ratio of 5.3 after adjusting for the APOE ε4 allele. Experimental studies demonstrated that this missense variant had deleterious effects on TM2D3 function, confirming its potential pathogenic role, which was initially overlooked by prediction algorithms.
title: Alzheimer’s disease-associated TM2D genes regulate Notch signaling and neuronal function in Drosophila

finding: The SNP rs3204689 was found to have a significant association with severe hand osteoarthritis (OA), with an odds ratio of 1.46, based on a genome-wide association study (GWAS). In the UK Biobank replication study, it showed a noteworthy odds ratio of 1.15 (95% CI 1.08-1.23, p = 2.5×10^-5), consistent with the expression patterns observed where lower levels of ALDH1A2 mRNA were detected in cartilage from individuals homozygous or heterozygous for this risk variant.
title: Variants in ALDH1A2 reveal an anti-inflammatory role for retinoic acid and a new class of disease-modifying drugs in osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs4238326 was similarly associated with severe hand osteoarthritis, showing an odds ratio of 1.44 in the initial GWAS, which replicated with an odds ratio of 1.16 (95% CI 1.09-1.25, p = 1.1×10^-5) in the UK Biobank. The study also revealed significantly reduced ALDH1A2 mRNA levels in cartilage from individuals carrying the risk alleles of this SNP, indicating its potential role in the pathogenesis of hand OA.
title: Variants in ALDH1A2 reveal an anti-inflammatory role for retinoic acid and a new class of disease-modifying drugs in osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs539846 was determined to be a causal SNP linked to Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL), with nucleotide-level models leading to its successful identification.
title: Cross-species prediction of transcription factor binding by adversarial training of a novel nucleotide-level deep neural network

finding: This variant remained associated with DKD, though the strength of the association was reduced in the larger dataset, suggesting its potential role in renal disease.
title: Genome-wide association study of diabetic kidney disease highlights biology involved in renal basement membrane collagen

finding: The variant rs1879454 was predicted to regulate TLNRD1 expression and was associated with the 15q25.1 CAD risk locus. The A allele of this SNP disrupted a GATA transcription factor motif and was linked to a 2-fold decrease in allele-specific GATA2 ChIP-seq signal and a 2.4-fold decrease in allele-specific ATAC-seq signal, indicating its significant role in the regulation of endothelial gene expression related to CAD.
title: Mapping the convergence of genes for coronary artery disease onto endothelial cell programs

finding: The SNP rs146353869, located in the FAN1 gene, was associated with a 6.1-year alteration in age of onset (AOO) for Huntington disease (HD). This SNP was reported to have a minor allele frequency of 2% and represented one of the previously identified modifiers with the largest known effect size in HD. However, it was considered less impactful compared to the newly identified loss of interruption (LOI) variant in the HTT gene, which resulted in an average AOO hastened by 25 years for its carriers.
title: Length of uninterrupted CAG repeats, independent of polyglutamine size, results in increased somatic instability and hastened age of onset in Huntington disease

finding: The SNP rs5742915 was identified as a potential causal variant in the PML gene for several biomarkers including FEV1-FVC ratio with a PIP of 0.858, pulse rate (PIP = 1.000), and total protein level (PIP = 0.987). This finding suggested its role in coordination mechanisms among vital organs.
title: SparsePro: an efficient genome-wide fine-mapping method integrating summary statistics and functional annotations

finding: The p.R153H variant (rs12595158) was nominally associated with a reduced risk for PD, with its association confirmed across cohorts, although it did not reach statistical significance in all cohorts compared to the New York cohort.
title: Analysis of common and rare VPS13C variants in late onset Parkinson disease

finding: The p.I398I variant (rs9635356) was also nominally associated with a reduced risk for PD, supporting its potential role in protection, however similar to p.R153H, it lacked consistent statistical significance across all cohorts.
title: Analysis of common and rare VPS13C variants in late onset Parkinson disease

finding: The p.I1132V variant (rs3784635) remained statistically significant after multiple comparisons adjustments, indicating a strong association with a reduced risk for PD in the New York cohort.
title: Analysis of common and rare VPS13C variants in late onset Parkinson disease

finding: The p.Q2376Q variant (rs17238189) was nominally associated with a reduced risk for PD, confirming the protective potential of this variant as part of the identified haplotype.
title: Analysis of common and rare VPS13C variants in late onset Parkinson disease

finding: Linked to disease in FinnGen, this variant was among four putative causal variants in the PCSK6 locus, highlighting multivariate analysis' significance for uncovering associations.
title: An expanded analysis framework for multivariate GWAS connects inflammatory biomarkers to functional variants and disease

finding: The SNP rs11070970 was associated with the expression levels of miR-221 and miR-222 in cancer patients. This association was part of a systematic review and meta-analysis that identified the prognostic role of these microRNAs in cancer, implying potential relationships between this SNP, metabolic pathways, and clinical outcomes such as survival probability.
title: Cancer metabolic subtypes and their association with molecular and clinical features

finding: The SNP rs28890483 was associated with common variants of the DRACC1 gene, which were found to potentially increase the risk of schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and alcohol dependence. This association highlighted the relevance of DRACC1's expression level in neuropsychiatric disorders.
title: DRACC1, a major postsynaptic protein, regulates the condensation of postsynaptic proteins via liquid-liquid phase separation

finding: The SNP rs10519005 was also linked to common variants of the DRACC1 gene, similarly suggesting a role in heightening the risk of schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and alcohol dependence. Furthermore, it pointed to the significance of DRACC1 as a hub gene in relation to susceptibility to depression, thereby implicating it in the modulation of neuronal activity and involvement in major depression.
title: DRACC1, a major postsynaptic protein, regulates the condensation of postsynaptic proteins via liquid-liquid phase separation

finding: The SNP rs5030784 was connected to the DAO gene, associated with cognitive ability in schizophrenia, with a p-value of 7×10^-6, highlighting its role in cognition.
title: Comparing the XGBoost machine learning algorithm to polygenic scoring for the prediction of intelligence based on genotype data

finding: The SNP rs528350911 was identified within the enhancer region approximately 664 kb from the ONECUT1 promoter. It was characterized as a high-confidence type 2 diabetes (T2D) associated variant that disrupted a GATA motif. Functional studies demonstrated that introduction of this risk variant into human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) led to a significant reduction in binding of key pancreatic transcription factors GATA4, GATA6, and FOXA2, though it caused only a mild effect on ONECUT1 transcription itself. This finding supported the hypothesis that rs528350911 contributes to metabolic disease by impairing enhancer activity, which is critical for pancreatic differentiation and development.
title: CRISPR Screening Uncovers a Long-Range Enhancer for ONECUT1 in Pancreatic Differentiation and Links a Diabetes Risk Variant

finding: The rs12906125 variant was determined to be a significant regulatory variant for the genes FURIN and FES. This SNP was shown to impact vascular endothelial cell senescence through CRISPR activation, resulting in a significant up-regulation of both genes with a log2(fold-change (FC)) of 3.75 for FES, indicating its potential role in CAD.
title: CRISPR perturbations at many coronary artery disease loci impair vascular endothelial cell functions

finding: This SNP was linked to the risk of obesity, demonstrating how genetic factors can influence body weight and thereby potentially relate to heart failure under certain circumstances.
title: Identification of biomarkers, pathways and potential therapeutic targets for heart failure using bioinformatics analysis

finding: The variant rs4238361 was identified as a potential risk-modifying variant for Parkinson's Disease (PD). This SNP is located near the gene VPS13C, which has been associated with both rare and common PD variants of interest. The findings suggested that this genetic variant might play a role in modifying the risk of developing PD.
title: Multi-Modality Machine Learning Predicting Parkinson’s Disease

finding: SIA detected a moderate signal of selection at the OCA2 locus, evidenced by a selection probability of 0.75 and a selection coefficient around 0.0056, relating to pigmentation traits.
title: SIA: Selection Inference Using the Ancestral Recombination Graph

finding: The SNP rs11070948 was associated with stearoyl-CoA desaturase (SCD) 1 as a therapeutic target in cancer treatment. This finding related to the identification of vulnerabilities in acute myeloid leukemia (AML) linked to fatty acid desaturation and indicated that certain genotypes might predict response to SCD inhibition therapies.
title: SCD inhibition preferentially eradicates AML displaying high de novo fatty acid desaturation and synergizes with chemotherapy

finding: The SNP rs1979858 was the top SNP by eQTL probability for CCDC106 and was located on chromosome 15. Its significance was driven by trans-eQTL effects, indicating correlation with CCDC106 expression.
title: Cis- and trans-eQTL TWAS of breast and ovarian cancer identify more than 100 risk associated genes in the BCAC and OCAC consortia

finding: SNP rs11070959 was associated with the methylation dynamics of the gene RASSF1A, which impacted cancer progression as found in 'Malpeli et al. (2019)'. The study observed altered methylation patterns that correlated with the severity of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC).
title: Altered DNA methylation in ion transport and immune signalling genes is associated with severity in Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma

finding: The SNP rs2470102 was associated with skin colour variation in Indian populations. It was identified as a predicted target site for miR-1180-3p in the MYEF2 gene, which has also been linked to skin colour, although the functional relationship remains unclear. A strong association between absolute latitude and the frequency of the target allele was noted, suggesting selection pressures based on UV exposure.
title: Pervasive selection against microRNA target sites in human populations

finding: The SNP rs17293632 was identified as a Crohn's disease-associated variant and an allele-specific binding (ASB) SNP for transcription factors JUN and FOS. It had the highest absolute value of the ΔMOCCS2score at 226.1, indicating a strong influence on FOS binding, which accounted for 40% of the ΔMOCCS2scores of the top 100 ChIP-seq samples. This suggested that the ΔMOCCS2score could effectively predict the impact of GWAS-SNPs on TF binding specificity.
title: MOCCS profile analysis clarifies the cell type dependency of transcription factor-binding sequences and cis-regulatory SNPs in humans

finding: This SNP was found to be correlated with SBP/DBP and was paired with rs2677738, showcasing a correlation of 0.49. It was part of the 12 known SNPs identified in the GWAS catalog.
title: Iterative Hard Thresholding in GWAS: Generalized Linear Models, Prior Weights, and Double Sparsity

finding: This SNP's association with elevated SBP/DBP was noted, being correlated with rs7497304, with a correlation coefficient of 0.49.
title: Iterative Hard Thresholding in GWAS: Generalized Linear Models, Prior Weights, and Double Sparsity

finding: The finding related to rs12913832 noted that the mutation causing blue eyes is a one-letter alteration in the HERC2 gene. The ancestral allele at rs12913832 stimulated melanin production, resulting in dark-brown eyes, whereas the mutated allele significantly reduced melanin production, leading to blue eyes. This SNP was linked to eye color variation and was derived from research concerning eye pigmentation patterns in a large, single-ethnicity population in Italy.
title: Sex tweaks eye color

finding: The R264C polymorphic variant of CYP19A1 was reported to show only 15% of aromatase activity when paired with WT-POR. In contrast, it retained 6.7% when paired with P284T-POR and around 5% with Y607C-POR, indicating a considerable reduction in activity. Its occurrence was significantly higher in Asian and African populations, with MAFs of 0.17, 0.24, and 0.18 respectively, but was low in European populations (MAF 0.02). The presence of R264C was linked to alterations in steroid metabolism.
title: Differential effects of variations in human P450 oxidoreductase on the aromatase activity of CYP19A1 polymorphisms R264C and R264H

finding: The R264H variant of CYP19A1, noted as a rare variant with MAF of 0.00003 in ExAc and 0.00002 in gnomAD-Exomes, was shown to have 87% of aromatase activity using the WT-POR as a redox partner. Remarkably, it exhibited a three-fold increase in activity compared to WT when paired with Y607C-POR. This variant also reflects potential significant impacts on estrogen synthesis and metabolic processes.
title: Differential effects of variations in human P450 oxidoreductase on the aromatase activity of CYP19A1 polymorphisms R264C and R264H

finding: This SNP was found within the IQGAP1 gene and reached genome-wide significance (P=3e-08) in the African meta-analysis for primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). It was previously unreported for POAG but associated in a nominal way in Asians.
title: A large cross-ancestry meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies 69 novel risk loci for primary open-angle glaucoma and includes a genetic link with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs2250072 was found in the SLC24A5 gene, which is considered a major driver of variation in skin pigmentation. This SNP was associated with evidence of positive selection in European populations, indicating its role in adaptive traits related to light skin pigmentation.
title: A fast linkage disequilibrium-based statistical test for Genome-Wide Epistatic Selection Scans in structured populations

finding: The SNP rs11071037 was linked to the role of AP-1 transcription factors as regulators of immune responses in cancer. The study published in 2019 by Atsaves et al. outlined the connection between the genetic variation represented by this SNP and immune signaling, specifically in the context of cancer pathology. The findings illustrated how variants like rs11071037 could influence transcription factor activity, therefore impacting immune response mechanisms within tumors.
title: TCR signaling promotes the assembly of RanBP2/RanGAP1-SUMO1/Ubc9 nuclear pore subcomplex via PKC-θ-mediated phosphorylation of RanGAP1

finding: Rs13737 showed a negative effect size on MAN2C1 across all investigated tissues. MAN2C1 is implicated in cellular growth and apoptosis, with suggested involvement in the PI3K-AKT signaling pathway, relevant to T2D susceptibility.
title: Understanding functional consequences of type 2 diabetes risk loci using the universal data integration and visualization R package CONQUER

finding: The SNP rs4932265 was identified as influencing AP3S2 expression positively in all twelve tissues studied. AP3S2 is associated with vesicle budding from the Golgi and has been linked to T2D in various GWASs.
title: Understanding functional consequences of type 2 diabetes risk loci using the universal data integration and visualization R package CONQUER

finding: The SNP rs11071008 was associated with ovarian cancer dynamics and relevant mechanobiological factors, indicating its significance in understanding tumor microenvironments, as discussed in research featured in Cancers in 2019.
title: A flexible micro-piston device for mechanical cell stimulation and compression in microfluidic settings

finding: The TRPM7 rs8042919 genotype was analyzed in the context of the Personalized Prevention of Colorectal Cancer Trial (PPCCT), which investigated its interaction with magnesium supplementation aimed at reducing colorectal carcinogenesis biomarkers. This study included participants aged 40-85 with a personal history of colorectal polyps and specific calcium intake criteria. The findings suggest that this SNP may influence how magnesium affects colorectal cancer risk, highlighting the relevance of TRPM7 genotype in colorectal health.
title: On the robustness of inference of association with the gut microbiota in stool, swab and mucosal tissue samples

finding: The Ap3s2 gene rs2028299 was also linked to type 2 diabetes in the northern Chinese Han population, further supporting the genetic basis for diabetes susceptibility.
title: Analysis of key genes and pathways associated with the pathogenesis of Type 2 diabetes mellitus

finding: The SNP rs1426654 in SLC24A5 had the largest selection difference between Europeans and East Asians, indicating strong directional selection in Europeans and suggesting its important role in light pigmentation.
title: Dissecting dynamics and differences of selective pressures in the evolution of human pigmentation

finding: The SNP rs1800414 in the OCA2 gene displayed large selection differences between East Asians and other populations, indicating potential selection for light pigmentation traits in East Asians.
title: Dissecting dynamics and differences of selective pressures in the evolution of human pigmentation

finding: The SNP rs1800401 in OCA2 was associated with dark pigmentation, and exhibited significant selection difference indicating its potential role in pigmentation adaptations.
title: Dissecting dynamics and differences of selective pressures in the evolution of human pigmentation

finding: The variant rs1051168 was identified as a progenitor eSNP regulating NMB gene expression, associated with a p-value of 2.78e-09. It was colocalized with the schizophrenia (SCZ) index SNP rs12908161 and demonstrated that the risk allele (G) correlated with decreased NMB expression, linking it to schizophrenia risk.
title: Genetic influences on cell type specific gene expression and splicing during neurogenesis elucidate regulatory mechanisms of brain traits

finding: As the index SNP for schizophrenia, rs12908161 was found to colocalize with the progenitor eSNP rs1051168, which regulates NMB gene expression. This association suggests a specific regulatory mechanism contributing to schizophrenia susceptibility through the NMB-related pathway.
title: Genetic influences on cell type specific gene expression and splicing during neurogenesis elucidate regulatory mechanisms of brain traits

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was highlighted for its role in modulating human pigmentation by affecting chromatin-loop formation between a long-range enhancer and the OCA2 promoter. This regulatory relationship was relevant for both pigmentation and melanoma risk in humans, suggesting an intricate connection between genetic variants and the mechanisms underlying skin color and melanoma susceptibility.
title: Transcriptional co-activator regulates melanocyte differentiation and oncogenesis by integrating cAMP and MAPK/ERK pathways

finding: This variant was part of the three replicated pairs associated with skin color interactions. It displayed significant interaction with rs1805008 when analyzing SNPs related to hair and skin color.
title: Dispensing with unnecessary assumptions in population genetics analysis

finding: The study identified rs1655558 as a potential causal variant influencing the expression of the long non-coding RNA OIP5-AS1 in various brain cell types, particularly excitatory neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes. This finding was significant as it highlighted the role of OIP5-AS1 in interactions with HDAC proteins, notably HDAC11, which were associated with the presence of tau tangles and amyloid plaques, key pathological features of Alzheimer's disease. The discovery that rs1655558 could serve as a genetic driver for OIP5-AS1 expression underscores its relevance in the context of Alzheimer's disease pathology.
title: Spatial Expression of Long Non-Coding RNAs in Human Brains of Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: Evidence for association was found for rs4779584, with a reported p-value of 0.018 in the context of colorectal cancer risk. This variant was previously flagged in multiple genome-wide association studies, affirming its relevance in understanding genetic predispositions to colorectal cancer.
title: Genetic Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer in Multiethnic Indonesians

finding: The SNP rs11632715 replicated with a significant association (p=0.004) in colorectal cancer cases. Its inclusion in previous GWAS reinforced the need for further investigation into its mechanism within the context of cancer risk.
title: Genetic Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer in Multiethnic Indonesians

finding: The SNP rs73376930 was replicated and associated with colorectal cancer (p=0.010), highlighting its role alongside other identified variants in promoting risk. It reinforced the findings from earlier gene association studies focused on colorectal cancer.
title: Genetic Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer in Multiethnic Indonesians

finding: The SNP rs10083612, with a notable p-value of 1.61e-5, was identified within an intron of the SCG5 gene, marking it as the strongest associated SNP in the analyzed region on chromosome 15. This finding points towards significant involvement of SCG5 in colorectal cancer risk factors.
title: Genetic Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer in Multiethnic Indonesians

finding: The SNP rs3784609 was linked to RORA, a lipid-sensing nuclear receptor that was broadly lowly expressed in cerebrovascular cells, including capillary and venule endothelial cells, pericytes, and fibroblasts. High expression of SOCS3, an inflammation repressor regulated by RORA, was noted in capillary and venule endothelial cells in Alzheimer's disease (AD), indicating a potential molecular pathway influencing pathological retinal angiogenesis.
title: Single-cell multi-region dissection of brain vasculature in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs442495 was found in association with ADAM10, a key modulator of dendritic spine formation linked to Alzheimer's pathology. ADAM10 was identified as differentially expressed in various cell types and was connected through ligand-receptor interactions, demonstrating significant downstream effects on genes associated with lipid storage, immune response, and cell proliferation in capillary endothelial cells.
title: Single-cell multi-region dissection of brain vasculature in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs2140734 was identified as the top GWAS variant associated with Huntington disease and was linked to a delay in onset by 1.4 years. It demonstrated a significant association with the expression of the gene MTMR10 in a larger cortical dataset, with a Spearman’s rank correlation of 0.24 (P=8.51 × 10^-8). This association was further validated using eQTL data showing a normalized effect size of 0.38 (P=3.2 × 10^-7) in the cortex, linking the SNP to both Huntington disease onset and gene expression modulation.
title: Gene expression profiles complement the analysis of genomic modifiers of the clinical onset of Huntington disease

finding: The SNP rs78366152 was discovered as a cell type-specific (CTS) cis-eQTL for the AD risk gene AP3B2. It was noted for its significance in microglia, oligodendrocyte, and astrocyte cell types, but not in excitatory neurons. The variant was previously undetected as an eQTL for AP3B2 in ROSMAP bulk brain RNA-seq data. It resided in a microglia-specific ATAC-seq peak that formed a chromatin loop with the promoter region of AP3B2, suggesting a microglia-specific regulatory effect.
title: Cell-type specific inference from bulk RNA-sequencing data by integrating single cell reference profiles via EPIC-unmix

finding: The rs17293632 variant in the SMAD3 region was found to have a high posterior probability (40%) as a causal variant in Crohn's disease studies. It was associated with the risk of asthma and coronary artery disease. MENTR predicted that the T allele of this SNP decreased the expression of enhancer ADDG15067442347.E across various cell types relevant to these diseases, confirming its role in transcriptional regulation and its interactions within complex disease mechanisms.
title: Predicting cell-type-specific non-coding RNA transcription from genome sequence

finding: The study established an association with a single nucleotide polymorphism (rs11547207) located in the CIB2 gene, which showed a significant association (p=1.85 x 10^-27) with cis-eQTLs in retinal tissues from human AMD patients. This finding underscores the relevance of CIB2 in the context of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and suggests that variations at this locus may influence the expression of genes involved in AMD pathology.
title: CIB2 regulates autophagy via Rheb-mTORC1 signaling axis

finding: The strongest association was observed with this SNP on chromosome 15q14, showing remarkable links to precentral SA (P-value of 1.8 x 10^-137 and replicated as 4.6 x 10^-189), indicating its critical role in hand motor function and possibly in synaptic integrity.
title: The genetic architecture of the human cerebral cortex

finding: The SNP rs35755513 had been detected previously in association with neuroticism and was classified as a potentially pathogenic variant.
title: Gene-based association analysis identified 190 genes with polymorphisms affecting neuroticism

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was identified as the key regulatory element influencing the expression of OCA2, with the T-allele facilitating chromatin loop formation and enhancing transcription, whereas the C-allele obstructed this process. This variant was associated with eye colour variation, particularly relevant in European populations, where it primarily contributed to blue eye colour.
title: Investigating the genetic architecture of eye colour in a Canadian cohort

finding: This SNP was highlighted as one of the significant markers in the HERC2 locus, associated with eye colour variation.
title: Investigating the genetic architecture of eye colour in a Canadian cohort

finding: This SNP was found to be associated with eye colour in the fine-mapping analysis.
title: Investigating the genetic architecture of eye colour in a Canadian cohort

finding: The SNP rs28374715 was associated with an increased risk of ulcerative colitis (UC) with a p-value of 2.43E-08 and an odds ratio of 1.08 (1.04-1.13) in European ancestry individuals. This finding highlighted that genetic variants in the RTF1 region could influence susceptibility to UC.
title: RTF1 mediates epigenetic control of Th17 cell differentiation via H2B monoubiquitination

finding: The SNP rs2777491 was associated with a decreased risk of ulcerative colitis, with a p-value of 8.32E-08 and an odds ratio of 0.94 (0.91-0.96) in European ancestry individuals. This finding indicated a protective genetic variant related to the RTF1 gene in the context of UC.
title: RTF1 mediates epigenetic control of Th17 cell differentiation via H2B monoubiquitination

finding: The SNP rs12440045 exhibited a robust association with neutrophil counts, suggesting its involvement in the immune response. Considering that IL-17A plays a crucial role in neutrophil mobilization and that neutrophil infiltration is a hallmark of UC disease severity, this SNP suggested a link between RTF1 regulation and IBD through modulation of neutrophil activity.
title: RTF1 mediates epigenetic control of Th17 cell differentiation via H2B monoubiquitination

finding: The rs3825807 variant, which results in a p.Ser214Pro coding alteration, was associated with increased maturation and processing of the ADAMTS7 prodomain. This alteration correlated with heightened degradation of COMP (Cartilage oligomeric matrix protein) and facilitated vascular smooth muscle cell migration. Furthermore, the Ser214 risk allele indicated a connection with unstable atherosclerotic plaque phenotypes and increased rates of secondary cardiac events. In mouse knockout studies, loss-of-function of Adamts7 significantly reduced neointimal formation following arterial wire injury, supporting the role of ADAMTS7 in vascular smooth muscle cell behavior.
title: TAILS identifies candidate substrates and biomarkers of ADAMTS7, a therapeutic protease target in coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs11071021 was identified as a significant marker related to breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) in the study. This genetic variation was correlated with the behavior of TNBC, particularly in the context of immune recognition and the ability of γδ T cells to target BCSCs. The findings suggested that changes in the expression of ligands associated with γδ T cells could impact the therapeutic efficacy of immunotherapies in TNBC, highlighting the relevance of this SNP in developing novel treatment strategies.
title: Breast cancer stem cell-derived tumors escape from γδ T cell immunosurveillance in vivo by modulating γδ T cell ligands

finding: Variant rs56350203, located at chr15:70140778:G:C, acted as a caQTL for a cRE upstream of the TLE3 gene. The G allele was associated with increased accessibility in acinar cells (effect=0.70, FDR=9.7×10^-13) but decreased activity in alpha cells (effect=0.37, FDR=1.9×10^-12). This finding highlighted the variant's differing effects on gene accessibility between pancreatic cell types.
title: Single cell multiome profiling of pancreatic islets reveals physiological changes in cell type-specific regulation associated with diabetes risk

finding: The SNP rs269868 was associated with a positive original finding in the context of adaptation to the Andean environment. This missense mutation (C>T:Ser1067Leu) showed an ancestral allele that had been positively selected in the Andes compared to Amazon populations, where its C allele frequency was 0.01 versus 0.53 in Andean populations. This SNP is located in an A-loop region of DUOX2, suggesting potential impacts on the stability and maturation of the DUOX2 dimer involved in producing hydrogen peroxide essential for various immune functions.
title: The genetic structure and adaptation of Andean highlanders and Amazonian dwellers is influenced by the interplay between geography and culture

finding: The SNP rs57659670, another missense mutation (T>C:His678Arg), was also identified as undergoing positive selection in the Andes. Similar to rs269868, the allele frequency for the C allele was 0.53 in Andean populations and only 0.01 in the Amazon, indicating a clear adaptive pressure. The findings suggest that mutations in this region, related to DUOX2, might play a role in adapting to environmental stresses in the Andes, especially regarding thyroid and immune function.
title: The genetic structure and adaptation of Andean highlanders and Amazonian dwellers is influenced by the interplay between geography and culture

finding: The DISP2 rs183775254 variant was negatively associated with age (-12 years in meta-analysis) and was the top age-related variant, found to decrease in allele frequency with increasing age. Its association was replicated in two independent cohorts, demonstrating significant consistency in its effect.
title: Exome-wide association studies in general and long-lived populations identify genetic variants related to human age

finding: An association was discovered for the phenotype "Use of sun/uv protection" (UK Biobank Field ID: 2267) with the nonsynonymous SNP rs121918166 (MAF: 0.9%, p value: 5.2E-31). This SNP is found in the OCA2 gene, which is involved in pigmentation, and subjects who were reported to use sun/UV protection more frequently had a higher frequency of the minor allele T.
title: Efficient mixed model approach for large-scale genome-wide association studies of ordinal categorical phenotypes

finding: The analysis identified the nonsynonymous SNP rs117116488 as significant for the phenotype "Comparative height size at age 10" (UK Biobank Field ID: 1697), with a MAF of 0.99% and a p value of 1.4E-18, linked to the ACAN gene.
title: Efficient mixed model approach for large-scale genome-wide association studies of ordinal categorical phenotypes

finding: This SNP was reported as one of those with a high likelihood of contributing to deleterious effects, linking it to risk loci associated with volumetric traits.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide analyses of the brain imaging phenotypes in UK Biobank

finding: The rs6224 variant was associated with schizophrenia, indicating that alleles increasing the odds of left-handedness also raised the risk of schizophrenia.
title: RSGenome-wide association study identifies 49 common genetic variants associated with handedness

finding: The SNP rs4702 in FURIN was studied as a putative causal variant associated with schizophrenia (SCZ). The investigation revealed that genotype-dependent transcriptomic differences were observed, which resulted in specific pre- and post-synaptic perturbations. This finding highlighted the potential of rs4702 to influence gene expression in a manner relevant to the pathogenesis of schizophrenia.
title: Convergent impact of schizophrenia risk genes

finding: Selection at rs1426654 in the SLC24A5 locus, also related to skin pigmentation, occurred even earlier than that at SLC45A2, reaching near fixation around 3,500 years ago, demonstrating critical responses to environmental pressures experienced in higher latitudes.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: This SNP represented a novel peak that reached significance specifically in the African tracts of the UK Biobank cohort. It exhibited a p-value of 1.915×10^-8 and lay in an intergenic region near the genes MEIS2 and C15orf41. Although its role in blood lipids was not clarified, MEIS2 had been associated with body mass index, while C15orf41 was a significant hit in a previous cholesterol GWAS.
title: Tractor: A framework allowing for improved inclusion of admixed individuals in large-scale association studies

finding: The C allele at rs2289702 was linked to increased expression of CTSH RNA, contributing to heightened susceptibility to T1D. This allele may enhance responses to viral infections and increase the risk of early diagnosed T1D among carriers due to its potential to cleave TLR3, thereby modifying immune responses.
title: Specific type 1 diabetes risk genes underpin age-at-diagnosis and indicate joint defects in immunity, beta-cell fragility and responses to viral infections in early-onset disease

finding: The SNP rs11070955 was linked to metabolic regulation of redox balance in cancer, particularly in pancreatic cancer, where PGC1a and PRC1 inhibition impacts mitochondrial function.
title: Integration of high-content fluorescence imaging into the metabolic flux assay reveals insights into mitochondrial properties and functions

finding: The SNP rs7163757 was implicated as the likely causal variant for type 2 diabetes (T2D) risk at the VPS13C/C2CD4A/C2CD4B locus. This variant was associated with marked effects on neighboring genes when targeted by CRISPR techniques, suggesting its role as an effector variant pertinent to glucose homeostasis and potentially influencing gene expression in relevant tissues, particularly the endocrine pancreas and brain.
title: Sexually dimorphic roles for the type 2 diabetes-associated C2cd4b gene in murine glucose homeostasis

finding: The SNP rs7172432 was reported to have a statistically significant impact (p=0.004) on waist circumference in human studies, which may relate to body weight changes observed in male C2cd4b knockout mice. Importantly, this variant was noted to be in perfect linkage disequilibrium (R²=1.0) with rs7163757, reinforcing its association with alterations in glucose metabolism and diabetic risk.
title: Sexually dimorphic roles for the type 2 diabetes-associated C2cd4b gene in murine glucose homeostasis

finding: The rs4924345:C minor allele was found to have strong positive effects on bilateral central sulcus mean depth and surface area, while also showing negative effects on several neighboring sulcal measures.
title: Genetic map of regional sulcal morphology in the human brain

finding: The SNP rs16971798 of NUSAP1 was implicated in a potential epistatic genetic interaction with tau filaments, indicating that this genetic variant may influence the pathology associated with tau aggregation in Alzheimer's disease. The study provided evidence that a loss of function of NUSAP1 could lead to enhanced tau aggregation and highlighted that this protein was downregulated in Alzheimer's brain samples, suggesting its involvement in nucleolar dysfunction linked to tauopathies.
title: Genome-wide CRISPRi screening reveals regulators of Alzheimer’s tau pathology shared between exosomal and vesicle-free tau seeds

finding: The study identified rs7170151 as a functional variant that contributed to the enhanced expression of RASGRP1, particularly in Jurkat T-cells. It was shown to have significant enhancer activity, indicating its role in the regulation of immune responses relevant to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
title: Mechanistic characterization of RASGRP1 variants identifies an hnRNP K-regulated transcriptional enhancer contributing to SLE susceptibility

finding: rs11631591 was experimentally validated as a functional SNP with significant enhancer activity specific to T-lymphocytes. The risk allele (C) was shown to increase RASGRP1 expression and correlate with enhanced ERK signaling in cells involved in SLE pathology, suggesting it plays a critical role in SLE susceptibility.
title: Mechanistic characterization of RASGRP1 variants identifies an hnRNP K-regulated transcriptional enhancer contributing to SLE susceptibility

finding: Similar to rs11631591, rs7173565 exhibited significant enhancer activity in Jurkat cells, contributing to RASGRP1 expression regulation. Its proximity to rs11631591 further reinforced its potential contribution to SLE pathology.
title: Mechanistic characterization of RASGRP1 variants identifies an hnRNP K-regulated transcriptional enhancer contributing to SLE susceptibility

finding: This SNP was identified as a lead signal from a previous analysis. In this study, it correlated with other significant SNPs and may play a role in the genetic architecture of SLE by impacting RASGRP1 expression.
title: Mechanistic characterization of RASGRP1 variants identifies an hnRNP K-regulated transcriptional enhancer contributing to SLE susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs11070965 was associated with the regulation of cancer stem cells in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). In this context, studies highlighted the potential of targeting stemness-related pathways in TNBC cells, linking this SNP to improved understanding and treatment strategies for this aggressive cancer type.
title: Lysosomal acid lipase-activity as a novel target to efficiently address triple-negative breast cancer high malignancy

finding: Located in the CYP19A1 gene, this SNP yielded highly significant p-values for association with four out of six dyslexia traits evaluated, providing the strongest evidence for association in the study. It was robust irrespective of adjustments made for verbal IQ.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: This SNP was positioned 16.1 kb downstream of the CYP19A1 3' UTR and was associated with a predicted disruption of TF binding in the occipital lobe, suggesting it plays a role in regulating dyslexia-related phenotypes.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: The rare allele of this SNP showed a significant association with decreased performance on word reading tasks, highlighting its potential impact on dyslexia through regulatory variation in the CYP19A1 gene.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: The variant rs2301249 resulted in a reduction of GATA4-DNA binding affinity, though it did not show a statistically significant effect on luciferase activity. It was associated with decreased expression of genes such as ULK3 and CSK, suggesting a potential repressive role.
title: Cardiovascular Disease-Associated Non-Coding Variants Disrupt GATA4-DNA Binding and Regulatory Functions

finding: The SNP rs17293632 was associated with Crohn's disease and inflammatory bowel disease. It showed strong evidence from RegulomeDB for affecting disease risk through the minor allele T, which was found to reduce SMAD3 gene expression, thereby impacting the TGF-beta signaling pathway crucial for T cell activation and metabolism.
title: Annotating and prioritizing human non-coding variants with RegulomeDB

finding: This SNP was associated with varying anthropometric and pulmonary measures, and showed links to conditions such as schizophrenia and hypospadias.
title: Long-range regulatory effects of Neandertal DNA in modern humans

finding: The SNP rs2247233 was identified as the top SNP associated with enhancer enh41216, which is involved in a schizophrenia (SCZ) locus and resides within a super enhancer (SE). This SNP was crucial in linking the functionality of enh41216 as a causal transcript, as determined by FOCUS fine-mapping. Additionally, it was highlighted that the transcriptome-wide association study (TWAS) signal from enh41216 completely explained the GWAS significance for the associated SCZ locus.
title: Population-level variation of enhancer expression identifies novel disease mechanisms in the human brain

finding: This missense variant in the LOXL1 gene, identified as rs1048661 (p.Leu141Arg), was shown to confer a risk of developing exfoliation syndrome (XFS). It had a very high heterogeneity across populations as the effect of the allele showed reversal.
title: Analysis of Genetically Determined Gene Expression Suggests Role of Inflammatory Processes in Exfoliation Syndrome

finding: Also a missense variant in the LOXL1 gene, rs3825942 (p.Gly153Asp), was indicated to likely confer risk of XFS with significant population heterogeneity due to effect reversal seen in different populations.
title: Analysis of Genetically Determined Gene Expression Suggests Role of Inflammatory Processes in Exfoliation Syndrome

finding: Identified within the OCA2/HERC2 locus, this SNP was a primary determinant of light eye color in Europeans, reflecting selective pressures related to pigmentation during earlier human migrations.
title: 1,000 ancient genomes uncover 10,000 years of natural selection in Europe

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was associated with brown eye color in individuals with the GG genotype. This association was part of a larger study that explored the relationship between this SNP and others found in genes related to pigmentation, specifically TYR, TYRP1, and SLC24A4. The findings indicated a significant role of these SNPs in determining eye color.
title: Assessing and mitigating privacy risk of sparse, noisy genotypes by local alignment to haplotype databases

finding: The SNP rs12917011 was linked to OP with a GWAS P<sub>GWAS</sub> = 2.1E-06 and was associated with SPESP1 (P<sub>TWAS</sub> = 3.3E-08). This finding suggested the gene’s involvement in bone density regulation and its potential as a therapeutic target.
title: Integrating genome-wide association and transcriptome predicted model identify novel target genes with osteoporosis

finding: The finding for rs1800401 was important as it represented a specific missense variant (p.Arg305Trp) in the OCA2 gene, linked to albinism in the Kalinago population. This SNP contributed to the identification of genetic factors associated with reduced pigmentation in the albino individuals studied.
title: Native American Ancestry and Pigmentation Allele Contributions to Skin Color in a Caribbean Population

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was associated with the blue eye color phenotype and showed a substantial excess of identity-by-descent (IBD) segments, indicating strong recent positive selection. The estimated additive selection coefficient was calculated to be approximately 0.0225 (95% CI = (0.0196, 0.0254)), suggesting that this variant has undergone strong selection within the past two hundred generations.
title: Modeling recent positive selection in Americans of European ancestry

finding: The study found that the rs17514846 SNP in the human FES gene was correlated with differential Fes protein levels, where higher Fes levels were associated with increased cancer incidence rates (Hazard Ratio HR 1.03 [1.01 – 1.05], p=0.01) and risk of death (HR 1.06 [1.01 – 1.11], p=0.03) among individuals without cancer at baseline in a cohort of over 400,000 subjects from the United Kingdom Biobank. This finding indicated that reduced expression due to this SNP could have implications for cancer risk and outcomes.
title: Fes-deficient macrophages enhance CD8+ T cell priming and tumour control through increased proinflammatory cytokine production and presentation

finding: This SNP, located 54 kb 3' of ISG20, demonstrated a genome-wide significant association with hearing difficulty in the UK Biobank, with a p-value of 2.6e-5. This finding related to age-related hearing impairment (ARHI) confirmed its relevance in auditory function.
title: Biological insights from multi-omic analysis of 31 genomic risk loci for adult hearing difficulty

finding: The SNP rs4702, located in the 3'-UTR of the FURIN gene, was demonstrated to influence the expression of FURIN and susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection in human induced pluripotent stem cell (hiPSC) models. Allelic conversion from AA to GG led to decreased FURIN mRNA levels, reduced neurite outgrowth, and altered neuronal activity, indicating that the GG genotype was associated with lower FURIN expression in both alveolospheres and glutamatergic neurons. This was correlated with reduced infection rates of SARS-CoV-2 in cells representing both lung and neuronal tissue, thereby establishing a link between host genetic variation at rs4702 and clinical heterogeneity in COVID-19 outcomes.
title: Common genetic variation in humans impacts in vitro susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection

finding: The non-synonymous polymorphism rs16969968 (D398N) in the gene Chrna5 was associated with nicotine dependence, schizophrenia, and cognitive impairment in humans. This SNP resulted in nicotinic alpha4beta2alpha5 receptors exhibiting a partial loss of function, which was attributed to alterations in receptor desensitization, calcium permeability, or membrane trafficking.
title: Chrna5 is a marker of acetylcholine super-responder subplate neurons with specialized expression of nicotinic modulator proteins

finding: The study highlighted that the HERC2 rs12913832 SNP modulated human pigmentation by attenuating the chromatin-loop formation between a long-range enhancer and the OCA2 promoter. This finding was significant in the context of understanding the genetic mechanisms underlying pigmentation traits, linking the genetic variant to its functional role in chromatin architecture.
title: LungCancer3D: A Comprehensive Database for Integrating Lung Cancer Chromatin Architecture with Other Multi-omics

finding: The SNP rs3212335, an intronic variant in the GABRB3 gene, showed a significant maternal genetic effect on offspring birthweight with a p-value of 7e-6. This finding indicated that maternal genetic influence through this SNP impacts the birthweight phenotype, with GABRB3 being crucial for neurodevelopment and exhibiting parent-of-origin imprinting effects.
title: Modeling Parent-Specific Genetic Nurture in Families with Missing Parental Genotypes: Application to Birthweight and BMI

finding: The SNP rs11070948 was positively identified in the context of Stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), which acts as a key metabolic protein linked to cellular inflammation and stress. This finding was originally derived from research highlighting SCD1 as a therapeutic target in cancer, establishing a significant connection between this SNP and metabolic diseases such as cancer and metabolic syndrome.
title: Sequential dynamics of Stearoyl-CoA Desaturase-1(SCD1) /ligand binding and unbinding mechanism: A computational study

finding: The SNP rs372754794 exhibited a significant association with variation in L cone ratios, with a p-value of 1.67 x 10^-5. It was located in an intron of the non-coding RNA NR2F2-AS1, upstream of the NR2F2 gene. The minor (G) allele associated with reduced L cone ratio was found nearly exclusively in African American and African subjects, with a minor allele frequency of 0.0359. This association remained robust even when restricted to African American populations, where the adjusted p-value was 1.44 x 10^-4.
title: Spatiotemporal specification of green and red cones in human retinas and organoids

finding: The rs12913832 SNP was highly associated with the eye color phenotype. In the study involving 1925 Estonian individuals, nearly 96% of individuals with at least one ancestral allele (A) had brown eye color, contrasting with 80% in the GAN-generated artificial genomes (AGs). Additionally, 97% of blue-eyed individuals in the real dataset and 88% in the AGs were homozygous for the derived allele (G). This strong correlation was confirmed by chi-square tests which yielded highly significant p-values (< 2.2e-16), demonstrating that the AGs successfully replicated the genotype-phenotype association found in the real dataset.
title: Creating Artificial Human Genomes Using Generative Models

finding: This SNP was associated with the ASE of ADAM10 in TC, emphasizing gene-specific regulatory mechanisms relevant to AD.
title: Allele-specific analysis reveals exon- and cell-type-specific regulatory effects of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genetic variants

finding: The SNP rs11070952 was analyzed in the context of baseline ALBI grade, which was shown to impact the outcomes of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients treated with lenvatinib (LEN) in a multicenter study. The study found that patients with better hepatic reserve function, as measured by ALBI grade, exhibited higher objective response rates (ORRs) and longer overall survival (OS) when treated with LEN.
title: Therapeutic Efficacy and Safety of Lenvatinib for Unresectable Hepatocellular Carcinoma Beyond Progression with Sorafenib

finding: The SNP rs11070948 was linked to the regulation of stearoyl CoA desaturase 1 (SCD1), which in turn was identified as a therapeutic target for prostate cancer treatment. This relationship underscored the role of cVA, a product of SCD1, in promoting prostate cancer cell viability and growth, thereby highlighting the importance of this SNP in the context of oncogenic transformation.
title: Cis-vaccenic acid is a key product of stearoyl-CoA desaturase 1 and a critical oncogenic factor in prostate cancer

finding: rs12050604 was found to have a significant association with a p-value of 5.08 x 10^-7 in the context of Bipolar Disorder, indicating its relevance to the phenotype in the analyzed data.
title: BayesRB: a markov chain Monte Carlo-based polygenic genetic risk score algorithm for dichotomous traits

finding: The SNP rs200342067 in the FBN1 gene was identified as a novel, population-specific missense variant (E1297G) significantly associated with lower height in Peruvians. Each copy of the minor allele, with a frequency of 4.7%, was associated with a height reduction of 2.2 cm, making it the largest effect size known for a common height-associated variant. The variant was positively selected in the Peruvian population and was more frequent in Native American coastal populations compared to those from the Andes or Amazon.
title: A positively selected, common, missense variant in FBN1 confers a 2.2 centimeter reduction of height in the Peruvian population

finding: The SNP rs11070971 was associated with the efficacy of tebentafusp, which is a bispecific molecule used in redirecting T cells for the treatment of metastatic uveal melanoma. The study indicated that specific genetic variations could influence T cell reactivity and the effectiveness of the therapy. This finding was significant as it related to the therapeutic strategies in cancer treatments.
title: Tuning the potency and therapeutic window of ImmTAC molecules by affinity modulation

finding: The variant rs16969968 located in the gene CHRNA5 was identified as a known schizophrenia variant. This missense mutation was classified as one of the predicted damaging mutations that overlapped with known variants in NDD gene analysis.
title: Evolutionary constraint genes implicated in autism spectrum disorder across 2,054 nonhuman primate genomes

finding: The rs492571 SNP was found to create a new start codon in the 5'UTR of the NM_001286491.2 isoform, resulting in a fully upstream open reading frame (uORF) carrying 35 codons (including one stop codon). This was suggested as a potential contributor to the GWAS signal associated with triglycerides and HDL-cholesterol levels due to its location within the 5'UTR.
title: MORFEE: a new tool for detecting and annotating single nucleotide variants creating premature ATG codons from VCF files

finding: The study by Zhen et al. (2016) highlighted advancements in automatic individual tree crown detection methods, particularly emphasizing the use of lidar data for enhanced accuracy in delineating tree crowns.
title: Accurate tropical forest individual tree crown delineation from RGB imagery using Mask R-CNN

finding: SNP rs8040334 was evaluated for its ability to discriminate invasive species within Mediterranean dune ecosystems, which highlighted its role in ecological monitoring and the management of biodiversity, particularly regarding invasive species management.
title: Scientific opportunities for developing essential biodiversity variables from satellite remote sensing in the context of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework

finding: The SNP rs7163757 was associated with a T2D GWAS signal at the C2CD4A/B locus. This SNP colocalized with caQTL signals in type 1, 2a, and 2x muscle fibers, with the T allele linked to higher chromatin accessibility. Additionally, the caPeak activity centered on this SNP was validated in a muscle cell line, implicating the VPS13C gene, associated with insulin resistance.
title: Population-scale skeletal muscle single-nucleus multi-omic profiling reveals extensive context specific genetic regulation

finding: The SNP rs7162757, a caSNP within the C2CD4A/B locus, was linked to T2D and insulin sensitivity metrics. It highlighted a strong functional role in chromatin structure, particularly in relation to VPS13C gene activity.
title: Population-scale skeletal muscle single-nucleus multi-omic profiling reveals extensive context specific genetic regulation

finding: Similar to rs10502437, the rs12901372 SNP also showed significant colocalisation with eQTLs, suggesting that this SNP had a differential expression effect supporting the association with osteoarthritis.
title: Decoding the genomic basis of osteoarthritis

finding: The variant rs12915901 was identified as a key target in the functional characterization of the osteoarthritis genetic risk, indicating its crucial role in the disease's genetic architecture.
title: Decoding the genomic basis of osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs12913832 near the HERC2 locus showed strong evidence of selection, suggesting its important role in the evolution of skin pigmentation.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: Strong signals of selection were detected for the light allele of rs1635168 near the HERC2 locus, contributing to understanding genetic influences on skin pigmentation.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: At the SLC24A5 locus, rs2675345 showed evidence of continued selection post-admixture following the introduction of the light allele by Neolithic farmers.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: The SNP rs9920172 near OCA2 showed an elevated PBS signal, especially prominent in hunter-gatherer populations, indicating an early selection episode.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: The SNP rs15342, a T to C change at chr15:101070089, was connected to the gene LRRK1. This polymorphism destroyed a strong hexamer AATAAA, affecting an annotated poly(A) site 22 nt downstream. The analyses showed that the wildtype transcripts were polyadenylated while the variant transcript was not, with Termin(A)n tor classifying them with probabilities of 0.98 and 0.01, respectively. This alteration was expected to prevent cleavage at the downstream poly(A) site, leading to the use of a more distant poly(A) site, thereby extending the 3' UTR, which harbored extensive miRNA binding sites and RBP sites for 77 RBPs.
title: Termin(A)ntor: Polyadenylation Site Prediction Using Deep Learning Models

finding: The SNP rs762551 was analyzed in the context of caffeine metabolism among Lake Superior State University (LSSU) students. The study found that the allele frequencies for caffeine metabolism were 42.7% fast, 44.5% medium, and 12.8% slow, with the results supporting the hypothesis that LSSU student allele frequencies matched those of the general population. This SNP is located within the CYP1A2 gene, and its polymorphism determines the metabolism rate of caffeine, affecting individual responses to caffeine consumption.
title: Analysis of the CYP1A2 caffeine metabolism gene in the student population at Lake Superior State University

finding: The SNP rs11070893 was associated with pancreatic cancer and was included in the findings which discussed the relationships between nerves and pancreatic cancer, suggesting potential implications for therapeutic strategies.
title: Signature reversion of three disease-associated gene signatures prioritizes cancer drug repurposing candidates

finding: The SNP rs1426654 was linked to skin pigmentation, with the reference allele associated with light skin color prevalent in individuals of West Eurasian ancestry. This SNP was situated on exon 3 of the SLC24A5 gene on chromosome 15. An investigation within the pangenome revealed two alignments: one perfect match to the reference allele and one variant allele showing a single mismatch. A focused search within the European core genome corroborated earlier findings by exclusively identifying the reference allele.
title: Detecting High Scoring Local Alignments in Pangenome Graphs

finding: The blue eye recessive allele rs12913832/G was reported with a frequency of 55% in EAJ, closely resembling the frequency found in MAJ at 54.8%. This finding suggests that the allele related to blue eye color was common in both medieval and modern Ashkenazi Jewish populations.
title: Genome-wide data from medieval German Jews show that the Ashkenazi founder event pre-dated the 14th century

finding: Moderate evidence for selection was observed at rs12913832 within the OCA2/HERC2 gene, with the selection coefficient (s) estimated at approximately 0.002. This SNP is causally linked to eye color variations and indicated potential selection dating back to at least 50,000 years ago.
title: An approximate full-likelihood method for inferring selection and allele frequency trajectories from DNA sequence data

finding: This variant (C>T) was investigated for its role in the CTSH locus related to type 1 diabetes. It was noted to be in low linkage disequilibrium (r^2=0.26) with the disease-associated variant. Interestingly, the type 1 diabetes risk allele counter-intuitively conferred protection from beta-cell apoptosis, suggesting that apoptosis might not be the primary mechanism of disease aetiology in this region.
title: Specific type 1 diabetes risk genes underpin age-at-diagnosis and indicate joint defects in immunity, beta-cell fragility and responses to viral infections in early-onset disease

finding: The SNP rs1426654, located in the SLC24A5 gene, was identified as a skin-lightening mutation that is fixed in European populations. This mutation exhibited a high FST value of 0.985 between the CEU (European) and YRI (Yoruba) populations. It was noted that this SNP would not have been discovered through genome-wide association studies (GWAS) performed solely within European populations; however, it became highly detectable when analyses included admixed populations. This finding highlighted the increased power of GWAS in admixed populations to capture variants that are under different selection pressures compared to single-ancestry groups.
title: Admixed Populations Improve Power for Variant Discovery and Portability in Genome-wide Association Studies

finding: The genotype distribution of the CYP1A2 gene variant rs762551 showed that 8%, 56%, and 36% of the sampled Pakistani population were homozygous wild-type (C/C), heterozygous (C/A), and homozygous mutant (A/A), respectively. The study demonstrated a significant association with caffeine-induced hypertension with a chi-square statistic of χ²(2, N = 50) = 4.244 and a p-value of 0.039. The C allele was found to be associated with decreased CYP1A2 activity, which is linked to higher vulnerability to hypertension, thus providing evidence of genetic relevance to hypertension in the studied population.
title: Genetic Association of CYP1A2 Gene Variant (rs762551) with Caffeine Induced-Hypertension Susceptibility and Cytochrome P450 1A2 Protein Analyses

finding: The rs578595 SNP, located intronically within WDR72, was identified as influencing CaSR signaling pathways, further supporting the genetic basis of nephrolithiasis.
title: Genetic variants of calcium and vitamin D metabolism in kidney stone disease

finding: Within SLC24A5, rs1426654 was reported to correlate with skin color, suggesting that it has been influenced by population-specific adaptations.
title: Network-based analysis of allele frequency distribution among multiple populations identifies adaptive genomic structural variants

finding: The SNP rs12913832 in OCA was highlighted as likely evolving under adaptive pressures based on its association with specific phenotypic traits.
title: Network-based analysis of allele frequency distribution among multiple populations identifies adaptive genomic structural variants

finding: The SNP rs12914385 exhibited a strong association with lung cancer in the GENEVA study, achieving a p-value of 1.887 x 10^-15, marking it as the top signal in the 15q25.1 locus. Furthermore, it was also found to have a significant relationship with dichotomized smoking pack-years, showcasing a p-value of 1.364 x 10^-6. In a mediation analysis, the total effect of rs12914385 on lung cancer risk was primarily a direct effect (OR_NDE = 1.333), but there was a modest indirect effect through smoking pack-years (OR_NIE = 1.019), with a significant test of the indirect effect (p = 0.0494).
title: Efficient Estimation of Indirect Effects in Case-Control Studies Using a Unified Likelihood Framework

finding: Previously recognized as a strong candidate variant, its regulatory role was reinforced through testing, impacting the expression of related genes.
title: Comprehensive identification of coronary artery disease-associated variants regulating vascular smooth muscle cell gene expression

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was found to modulate human pigmentation by attenuating chromatin-loop formation between a long-range enhancer and the OCA2 promoter. This finding related specifically to the phenotype of pigmentation and illustrated the regulatory role that this SNP plays in gene expression through chromatin interactions.
title: BEHST: genomic set enrichment analysis enhanced through integration of chromatin long-range interactions

finding: The SNP rs12913832 revealed correlations with DNAm changes relevant to pigmentation phenotypes, enhancing understanding of its role in skin cancer susceptibility.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The SNP rs1800407 was associated with DNAm regarding pigmentation, highlighting its importance in genetic studies.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The rs757148409 SNP was identified as a putative loss-of-function (LoF) mutation found exclusively in schizophrenia (SZ) cases but absent in controls. This variant resulted in a premature stop codon (p.Arg89Ter), leading to a significant reduction (approximately 50%) in the protein expression of OTUD7A in human induced neurons derived from the SNP-carrying cells. Furthermore, functional analyses demonstrated that neurons harboring this mutation exhibited reduced dendritic complexity and decreased glutamatergic synapse development. The findings supported the hypothesis that the rs757148409 SNP may play a critical role in the neurodevelopmental mechanisms associated with SZ, particularly in relation to the 15q13.3 deletion syndrome.
title: Loss-of-function of OTUD7A in the schizophrenia-associated 15q13.3 deletion impairs synapse development and function in human neurons

finding: The SNP rs2433603 located in the GATM gene was identified as significantly associated with estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) at a genome-wide significance level (p = 2.4 x 10^-9). This association was distinct from previously reported signals at the GATM locus.
title: Discovery and fine-mapping of kidney function loci in first genome-wide association study in Africans

finding: The SNP rs35346340 was identified as a potential causal variant at the FES/FURIN locus. It disrupted the TCF21 binding motif, which decreased FES expression while simultaneously increasing the expression of the nearby pro-differentiation gene FURIN. This SNP was shown to be an expression QTL for FES and lncRNA QTL for 43779.9, indicating its pivotal role in the regulatory interplay between these genes in the context of coronary artery disease.
title: LncRNA de novo discovery reveals noncoding RNAs as major molecular mechanism associating coronary artery disease GWAS variants with causal genes to confer disease risk

finding: The SNP rs7183988 was identified as a significant TCF21 binding QTL within the TCF21 peak at the FES/FURIN locus, highlighting its involvement in the modulation of gene regulation in the context of CAD risk.
title: LncRNA de novo discovery reveals noncoding RNAs as major molecular mechanism associating coronary artery disease GWAS variants with causal genes to confer disease risk

finding: SNP rs4932373 was recognized as an expression QTL for FES and lncRNA QTL for 43779.9, contributing to the regulatory mechanisms at the FES/FURIN locus, suggesting its relevance in CAD.
title: LncRNA de novo discovery reveals noncoding RNAs as major molecular mechanism associating coronary artery disease GWAS variants with causal genes to confer disease risk

finding: The SNP rs7497304 was found to be an expression QTL for FES and lncRNA QTL for 43779.9, further demonstrating its role in the regulatory landscape of the FES/FURIN locus and its potential contribution to CAD risk.
title: LncRNA de novo discovery reveals noncoding RNAs as major molecular mechanism associating coronary artery disease GWAS variants with causal genes to confer disease risk

finding: The SNP rs2071382 was identified as a CAD GWAS variant that decreased FES expression with the risk allele transition, implicating FES as a protective gene while concurrently suggesting FURIN as a disease-promoting gene.
title: LncRNA de novo discovery reveals noncoding RNAs as major molecular mechanism associating coronary artery disease GWAS variants with causal genes to confer disease risk

finding: The SNP rs8032315 demonstrated allele-specific enhancer activity under different stimulation conditions in neuronal cultures. The T allele showed increased activity under TTX conditions, while this relationship reversed under stimulation, aligning with eQTL effects on the FURIN gene.
